A human carcinogen is any substance that increases the risk of cancer.

QVC said the event — which runs from Thanksgiving evening to early Saturday morning — should set the tone for a strong shopping season that carries into the all-important post-Christmas season.
QVC’s Black Friday event differs from the in-store shenanigans favored by brick-and-mortar stores. The retailer, founded in 1986 by HSN parent company Liberty Interactive, typically delights shoppers with splashy videos of new toys, cosmetics and other retail treats in one- or two-hour blockbuster ‘Live Today’ programs during the holidays.

Innovation has always been associated with Chicago. We have a history of taking everyday objects and materials and using them to push the innovative boundaries of our time. Whether it be the Band Aid (created by Chicago natives Johnson & Johnson) or 3D printing (first conceptualized by Chicago native Charles Hull), Chicago has a history of innovation. Modern day Chicago holds a similar reputation. From world socio-mobile innovation through Level32, to innovative art through curator and collector Josef Olayvar, Chicago continues to push the innovation that historically makes up the Midwestern mecca.

Yes, these deaths are rare. Of the 4 million babies born each year, 340 mothers die, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the US health protection agency. Those numbers cover pregnancy and delivery, so a maternal death may occur before, after, or during birth.
That’s fairly typical for a western country.
The US, however, stands almost alone in the world in terms of how many women are killed.
As the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists points out, the maternal mortality rate in the US has doubled since the 1980s.
There are stark differences in the countries with the highest, and the highest, maternal mortality rates.

Of these, the company detailed clearly that Barbie dolls and the Disney/Pixar film franchise Cars continue to drag down patches of the business. The Barbie brand saw constant-dollar sales fall 10% in its most recent quarter, leading to a profit drop of 25% year over year. Falling prices are typically a sign of a healthy market, which Barbie hasn't had in recent quarters.

Consider the way a famous chef we known at HomeSciences trains his cooking students to perfect their art.
They all receive the same instruction, the same equipment, the same ingredients. What separates them from other aspiring chefs at the end of the training is nothing so much as touch. Some love doing it, some do it well, and some will never make it in the world of professional cooking.
Love is their secret ingredient.
We can teach you simple techniques to make a truly gratifying meal and any chef can learn the techniques, but touch is a troubling issue. It's perhaps the hardest kind of learning and yet the most important.

ZeedMe is a tool that allows high school students to paste a link to their Facebook profiles trusting schools to decide what kind of a student they are.
More than 160 schools already accept the application tool that the 2005 graduates of the University of Virginia and James Madison University founded after discovering Facebook last year. The schools claim to receive tens of thousands of applications using this tool.
So far, ZeeMee has proven to be successful. Colleges feature the test scores, GPA and SAT scores of the applicants after viewing their Facebook profiles and by telling some high school students they increased their chances of acceptance with the tool.

As one of the busiest large radio meteorologists in Concord — if not the busiest — Ray reliably weighs in on the news.
Head south three or four miles from Concord and you reach Lovewell Hill Reservoir in Franklin, powered by the dam you see to the left.
This important drinking water supply for many communities across the region (including a couple that don’t pay up though the Town of Franklin does) is completely full.
But it’s not wet enough here for the storm water basin behind the Union Jack Dam, the body of water created when the Weymouth Falls Paper Company (more about it here) dyed its rivers blue in the 1800s, flooded back in to the present reservoir.
That’s just the beginning of a strange situation clearly underway here, at least looking out over the water.

A: Schooners were common sea going vessels used in the days of sailing. Goods and people could travel the world aboard them.
A trials bottle with the words “To the Captain” was sent to the skipper of a ship announcing that the spirit contained in the bottle was of the best quality.
There are twelve writing holes on the bottom side made in the 1800’s so letters could be sent.
Shipping lines issued these schooner “to the Captain” bottles to officers calling on the owners with the assurance that even in the event that the captain fell of the boat during a transfer he would float.
This schooner bottle was a present crated in a dark oak box specially designed to keep spirits at the desired proof.

An additional $80 billion will be generated in 2002, so to the delight of tax auditors everywhere, the average number of audits is going down.
The impact of the recession and other economic factors have caused the decrease in audits. (Millions people have lost their jobs; fewer small businesses are keeping the books; fewer homes are being sold.) The combination of time, privacy concerns related to backup withholding for non-filers of tax returns, the voluntary disclosure initiative, and other factors have also contributed to the decline in audits.
Workers are more mobile and sales are more global. This has given rise to more people registering late, under-reporting income and other tax frauds. Increased audits take more time and additional resources. The government prefers to spend these resources for verification instead of tax fraud.

The state Bureau of Cannabis Control developed the guidelines for the zone system in the 2016 Business and Professions Code, which allow licensed adult use cannabis businesses to operate under zoning rules.
According to the resolution, 70 cannabis businesses in the Bay Area are in the draft zone system.

Balinese and other Indonesians also fought side-by-side with the Japanese during World War II.
The connection has all but disappeared as have many Balinese people. But the reference remained, a few still speak both languages with a familiar lilt, a language sustained by a small group of elderly people like 91-year-old Amelia Kadari.
Outside a small house, Amelia’s daughter, Eny Sankaersali, welcomes us to the modest dwelling and the woman who remains a bubbling repository of their tales.
“She speaks mostly Japanese,” Eny explains after a while, not referring to her mother’s skills with the language but that Amelia’s English isn’t quite sharp enough to explain the history that still captures everyone’s imagination. She wasn’t just Balinese either but also Bugis, South Sulawesi’s most Karianese language group.

On the surface, SB 837 looks like a great idea. We all want "kindergarten-ready" kindergartners. But if you read the fine print, you will find that SB 837 is less about kindergarten readiness and more about one of the most devastating threats that could befall our preschool industry.
Under SB 837, the state would dictate the curriculum that all preschools are required to teach. For example, all preschools would be required to include certain types of social studies curriculum and other curricula deemed appropriate by the state. Likewise, kids in preschool would be required to demonstrate certain things on a kindergarten-prep exam.

trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every one of us. Here are a few tips on how to deal with credit cards if you or a loved one is in over their head.
Before making any big decisions, you have to have a plan of action. A good rule of thumb is to only charge what you can pay off in one payment, and never carry a balance from one month to the next. If this means you are going to have to make sacrifices, so be it. Take a second job or cut as many expenses as you can out of your monthly budget. If your credit card bills are so large that you can't possibly hope to pay them off soon, the first thing you should do is contact your credit card company, explain your financial situation and ask for a lower interest

larger companies own their own servers, many smaller providers only have a limited number of servers to rent server space to clients. This means they rent interior server space to people looking for web hosting services.
People can save a substantial amount of money when purchasing web servers directly from a large site rather than going through a reseller as a middleman. However, some find it harder to deal with a large company directly, and prefer to have a reseller act as the intermediary. cells known as fibroblasts appear to work together to send a signal to the micro-environment around a cell to limit the growth or damage of genetic changes to the DNA.
The discovery — made using live fur-coated adult elephants, excised kidney and heart cells from a deceased elephant, and engineered human skin fibroblast cells — could help humans with cancer use drugs called senescent cells to block their cells from rapidly replicating themselves.
That could trick the body into regulating the cells, slow their growth and prevent the mitotic stage of reproducing into a cell that can spread in the body, Johns Hopkins Medicine said in a statement.
In humans with neo-plastic cancers, there can be up to 300 mitotic stages happening at once.

professionals identify the potential impact of the options they have with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, while the costs are mapped as a branch that leads off the decision tree. A well-constructed decision tree allows a decision maker to assess scenarios, such as the impact of purchasing a new manufacturing tool.
Decision trees graphs can evaluate the costs and consequences of various types of outcomes and allow decision-makers to see the impact various management styles have on the options a project manager considers when choosing to take a risk. A decision tree can help show the cost-saving impact it could have if the firm implements an operational risk management plan. This allows the decision-maker to reflect on the recent litigation the firm had experienced and how having the new operational risk management plan would have helped with the litigation and the organization's reputation.

Entitled "Deliver Us From Evil", the 100-minute film wows audiences with a dark and violent take on a budding matchmaking scene involving the precariat - a newly created class of people outside the protection offered by both tradition and law.
Rather than rehash the struggles of the working sub-classes of other Asian societies, director Park Dae-yeon frames these men and women as victims of a predatory marketplace made up of everything from matchmaking scams to fake HIV tests.
Without overstating the case, the film powerfully captures the sullen world of working people left with little recourse.

Many Gods Papers are happening.
I have invited people who are all wildly diverse about what Polytheist means and how it applies to their (and my own) own theological thoughts. Their proposals are respectful, profound, informative, innovative, and many other things. I wanted to have a place where people could make a ‘paper’ -a smaller independent project I can see.
There is no strict agenda other than to have something freaking awesome to read. A few projects have been turned down and others have been accepted to be turned into books one day. But the plan is to have a wide range diverse works and see where it takes us.
This initiative is independent, independent – not connected to the Many Gods West conference. (Unless people want it to be.) We can consider it independent, other people calling themselves ‘Pagan Polytheists’ or other fiefdoms can call us whatever they choose.

A study published earlier this year by the same research group discovered a strong link between so-called "warm grandmothers" — women with more positive maternal relationship with their granddaughters — and less fighting with their grandchildren.
Grandmothers are more unusual now than they have traditionally been. As fewer people move away after marriage, have children and raise a large family, there are fewer matrilineal grandmothers around than there once were. This situation has resulted in some challenges when it comes to family relationships among grandparents and grandchildren, with both groups sometimes having a difficult time adjusting to the absence of the nuclear family.

six important things to know about the history of the event.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, an environmental teach-in at college campuses across the country, on April 22, 1970.
The purpose was to force Americans to focus on their effects on the earth: "We rob the Earth first, and then compound the violence by robbing the Solar system, the Milky Way Galaxy, the entire universe and all the time wonder why the Earth doesn't see us one more year."

Clothes Lie and Why We Wear Them” (Riverhead Books), the Bloomsburg University sociologist Angela Y. Davis looks for food in the fashions of those who survive in a capitalist system.
Davis said the ways people treat their clothes often says more about the messages we take from the world than the shoes and jackets themselves.
“Clothing provides a powerful method of communication that delivers measurements of the history, economics, gender roles, religion and ideology of the people who make and own it,” Davis wrote in her book.
The clothing of those stranded on the Brooklyn side of the Manhattan bridge in 2003 showed more of their circumstances than the economic system they lived in, she said.
Their clothing also said a great deal about the New York (and national) political system they lived in.

of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many other Americans, he fell in love with Yosemite and was so moved by its beauty that he described it as the “best [he] ever saw in America.” And, a century later the national park still echoes with his broad embrace of conservation and the message he declared repeatedly: “Name the beauty of a tree. Find the courage to seek the law that binds tree and bird and man, one to another, fast in life, as in death.” Muir, a jumble of seeming contradictions, articulated the need for land conservation and wildlife protection well before environmentalism became a movement. “The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” connects this pioneering conservationist with other advocates of the Wild West – from paintings and literature to music and photography – and their mutual love of the American West. i approved the establishment of the Rail Development Authority (RDA) in March 2018.
The RDA will be a statutory body and a subsidiary of the Indian Railways.
Construction projects on railways have been marred by project delays, cost overruns, poor quality work and fraud.
As per the Union Cabinet the RDA will regulate policy formation coupled with the operationalisation and to enforce quality standards prevalent in other large infrastructural projects.
The Railways Ministry reported that projects worth about Rs. 7 lakh crore are stuck across the country, making them unable to connect.
Construction of India’s first high-speed train project was launched by the prime minister in September 2020.
The project will be executed by state-run railway company Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd.

my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a bonfire (I believe it was a bonfire), and making the shapes into sunflowers. My Mother noticed a strong talent for colour and pattern so she gifted me art supplies. From a young age my Mother always asked how I made things, so I would make ‘copies’ of books for her showing her how I did a process. I loved words so I wrote short stories, poems and then my mother bought me a typewriter.
In 1986 I was fortunate enough to study Art and Design for two years, luckily this was after the three years being kicked out of another college. My skill set was fine but study was not my strong point. Today I am thankful that during my school years I studied Latin and French, because learning to translate thoughts gives you words and sentences to form with your own thoughts too – the element of language inspires communication.

Let’s face it, baking soda gets a bad reputation. Since baking soda and baking powder contain similar chemical formulas (NaHCO3), most people tend to use the terms interchangeably. However, baking soda has a significantly different use compared to baking powder.

importance as one of the channels for people to connect – not only with friends, family and colleagues – but also to celebrities, brands and media properties, Nielsen Social Content Ratings enables clients to “successfully understand how their social content performs compared with competitors, drive more value from their content investments, make more confident planning decisions, and optimize their social media ads.”
Nielsen measures total audience size for various programming along with engagement – response or conversation (like, likes, re-tweets and post-shares).
Understanding what people are debating on social media about new and returning shows gives networks a chance to program appropriate social content. And it gives advertisers the chance to get involved based upon that conversation.
The report identified The Big Bang Theory as the most social primetime show this fall with total social engagements of 32 million – a 98% year-over-year improvement.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect the privacy rights of the European Union’s citizens will significantly affect business owners and consumers across the globe.
June 1 will mark the beginning of GDPR obligations. LBMC can help you prepare.
As the European Union’s (EU) new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) approaches, organizations worldwide are scrambling to understand exactly how the new law will affect their businesses.
While the final regulation was issued in April 2016, the effective date was delayed and a one-year transition period has been granted to all concerned organizations to prepare. When a cyberattack occurs, law enforcement needs to prove three points to successfully prosecute, according to David Pintillian, director of the Cybersafety Prosecution Service at the U.K.'s Cyber Crime Unit.
First, there must be sufficient evidence to show an offense has occurred. Next, there needs to be a perpetrator. Finally, law enforcement should have the appropriate jurisdiction to prosecute the criminal.

PayAnywhere's PAX-M, the cheapest credit card reader available, is a reliably priced, secure and serviceable credit card reader for mobile payments. Just don't rely on it for taking payments with the fastest turnaround times (it can take more than two hours to enter data manually after a transaction). For serious volume, consider alternative options (and get a lower transaction fee).
The PAX-M is one of two mobile credit card readers available from Chicago-based PayAnywhere. The other, a restaurant-specific credit card reader, is only recommended as a last resort to prevent you from losing the security of wireless credit card processing in your own store (you might not be able to pay your staff as quickly).

can choose a Creative Commons license – including the widely used Attribution (CC BY) license – during the upload process.
Creative Commons, and the sharing of images with a CC license, are a huge boon for photographers. As 500px points out in its announcement, the rental prices being demanded freelance photographers often are unreasonable, “and fees can soar if the photos are used in a print publication.”
A Creative Commons image can be used by some media without payment – the citation attribution is more than enough, and often the license restrictions are appropriate for the type of media coverage the photographer provides. Bloggers are also typically free to use images with a Creative Commons license, though it’s worth checking with the individual site for their own internal policies.
Public domain images are the gold standard of fair use (no license required at all), but they’re the rarity, not the norm.

The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a sub-agency of WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogenic agents and concluded the following:
In March 2008 the WHO organized a Special Working Group for a new evaluation of a number of natural and human-made substances. This group reviewed the provision of evidence and determined whether these agents are either “definite”, “probable”, or “not classifiable” as human carcinogens.
A human carcinogen is any substance that increases the risk of cancer.

The White House and conservative U.S. lawmakers went into last-minute discussions after congressional Republicans on Thursday revealed a plan to require President Barack Obama seek a delay of implementation of major healthcare reforms — which are subsidizing insurance for more than 10% of Americans — before he can sign a stopgap spending bill to avert a shutdown.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $20 million on prime-time Black Friday spots, three times the amount that it spent during last year’s holiday season, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.
QVC said the event — which runs from Thanksgiving evening to early Saturday morning — should set the tone for a strong shopping season that carries into the all-important post-Christmas season.
QVC’s Black Friday event differs from the in-store shenanigans favored by brick-and-mortar stores. The retailer, founded in 1986 by HSN parent company Liberty Interactive, typically delights shoppers with splashy videos of new toys, cosmetics and other retail treats in one- or two-hour blockbuster ‘Live Today’ programs during the holidays.

Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under which grants to states feed into a rebate system that enables fleets to upgrade older diesel trucks (and other vehicles) with more environmentally friendly equipment. DERA also for the first time sets a timeframe after which older trucks and buses will no longer be eligible for the program.
AAR applauded lawmakers for recognizing the North American clean air goal achieved through past versions of DERA. Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely.
Yes, these deaths are rare. Of the 4 million babies born each year, 340 mothers die, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the US health protection agency. Those numbers cover pregnancy and delivery, so a maternal death may occur before, after, or during birth.
That’s fairly typical for a western country.
The US, however, stands almost alone in the world in terms of how many women are killed.
As the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists points out, the maternal mortality rate in the US has doubled since the 1980s.
There are stark differences in the countries with the highest, and the highest, maternal mortality rates.
Yemen’s maternal mortality rate is 300 deaths per 100

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate Earth cousin with about the right conditions for life last week, researchers were pushing in a separate direction – the carbon.
The hunt for a so-called Goldilocks world – similar to our own planet, but located in a more suitable star system – has taken leaps forward in recent months with the discovery of the only planet-like object confirmed to orbit the right kind of star and the announcement of a planet whose parent star is close enough to the sun to potentially be converted into a water world.
As the excitement builds over the discovery of potentially promising planets, some astronomers are already focusing on a third candidate for habitability beyond the nitrogen and the oxygen. Proposing a hydrogen Earth in the quest for extraterrestrial life may at first seem a more speculative bet but increasingly, astronomers say, it is looking more and more likely.[...]

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.

Diascia personata can reach a height of 30cm. Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukraine had previously sought to pass on winter prices of about US$230 per 1,000 cubic metres (mcm), to its transit customers, which include Russia, Bulgaria, Turkey, Slovakia, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
With no agreement, Gazprom began returning the transit flow to the Russian market, a move condemned by the EU and United States.
Dmitry Medvedev, Russia’s prime minister, last week called on independent regulators to establish a gas market in Ukraine.
His comments were a signal that Russia may consider striking a direct gas deal with clients if cargo passes through Ukraine, arguing that a direct pipeline across the Ukrainian border was more economically attractive anyway (see gas dispatch: Last breath: the return of geo-economics).

The Eagles, after trading LeSean McCoy to the Buffalo Bills, might have found his replacement.
A person with knowledge of the situation, who requested anonymity, told NJ Advance Media that the Eagles have offered a signed tender to veteran running back Darren McFadden, who has a history with Eagles vice president of player personnel Ed Marynowitz while the two worked together with the Houston Rockets.
McFadden has played primarily in the NFL, gaining the status as a one-hit wonder when he posted 1,157 yards as a rookie with the Oakland Raiders, creating him with a defining NFL attribute as a pass-catching running back.
McFadden signed a one-year, $2.4 million deal with the Atlanta Falcons just before the season and played in 14 games with 401 yards and four touchdowns with five receptions for just 20 yards.
The Eagles granted him his release earlier this month and he remains an unrestricted free agent.

TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a place people sometimes take their dogs to for a walk.
But Sharon Fassor, the supervisor of the Turlock Golf Course Thursday came upon a group of ducks, all of whom had had their bills zip-tied so they couldn't eat.
"I will not have a park full of sickening ducks," she said.
Fassor immediately asked the city's code enforcement officer, April Blades, to make a call. Once the call was made, the ducks were let loose.
"That's what angers me the most, that they had no respect for the animals," Fassor explained.
Duck: "A horrible thing to see. It's the kind of people I don't want in my neighborhood."

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on Wednesday effectively rejected two proposed conservative initiatives to repeal or weaken the Liberals’ plan to cap the emissions from the oil and gas sector and to prick consumers’ appetites for gasoline and other fuels with more expensive ones.
Both the oil-and-gas emissions cap and a carbon tax on gasoline and diesel fuels are key planks of the Trudeau government’s panoply of measures to combat climate change. Both fuel the resistance from Canada’s oil and gas sector, which has taken aim specifically at the emissions cap and has been one of the fiercest critics of the carbon tax – which could apply next year.
In one corner, a sustained and vocal campaign has emerged to try to thwart the emissions cap measures touted in a joint federal-provincial statement last year in the prime minister’s Toronto-area riding.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way a famous chef we known at HomeSciences trains his cooking students to perfect their art.
They all receive the same instruction, the same equipment, the same ingredients. What separates them from other aspiring chefs at the end of the training is nothing so much as touch. Some love doing it, some do it well, and some will never make it in the world of professional cooking.
Love is their secret ingredient.
We can teach you simple techniques to make a truly gratifying meal and any chef can learn the techniques, but touch is a troubling issue. It's perhaps the hardest kind of learning and yet the most important.
A great meal doesn't have to be made with the most expensive equipment, the finest cuts of meat, or the choicest ingredients. It must be the stamp of your heart put into making

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered a series of statewide conservation measures a year ago to combat drought, including a ban on watering lawns with potable water and a reduction of urban car washing.
A statewide appeal to eat less meat is also in effect.
This week, the governor pronounced that a four-year drought think tank he convened had succeeded in helping find water supply solutions.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:17 p.m. city officials said.
When they got inside the home, they found the body of the three-year-old boy, who was pronounced dead at the scene.
Preliminary information revealed that the child may have died of smoke inhalation and hypothermia.
Chicago police said the family was home at the time of the fire and had exited the building on their own. The family reportedly lost a lot of personal property in the fire.
One firefighter suffered a leg injury when a ladder collapsed after the flames had been brought under control.
An area hospital treated him for the injury Sunday. A report did not indicate how serious the injury was.
Charges are pending after the incident, police said.
The neighborhood was unaffected by the fire with pedestrians carrying on with their days after the incident.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a magnificent intelligence. It allows him a particularly fertile grasp of the subtleties of what happens as the ball is bowled. It shows how the fiendish subtlety of the game lies in the transition from the ball in hand to the ball in creation, and how captains must wait until the action begins to anticipate the most effective response. Gets Your Goat, Brearley’s first volume of cricket anecdotes, is stripped of the air all too common in the best-selling mealanders of these afflictions.

TAYCHEEDAH - Two men were seriously injured Thursday night in a head-on crash in the town of Taycheedah.
A 35-year-old Fond du Lac man was eastbound on Highway CV in a pickup truck when he lost control on wet roads and crossed the centerline striking a westbound car driven by 84-year-old Joseph Gabricks of Genoa City.
A 55-year-old passenger from Genoa City was transported to a hospital by Gratz air ambulance with serious injuries.
The two other people in the vehicle were treated at the scene for some complaints of discomfort but did not need to be transported to a hospital.
The vehicles were totaled by the crash and the road was obstructed for the remainder of the night.
The incident remains under investigation by the Dodge County Sheriff"s Department.

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 28-29 September Asean summit.
Foreign journalists will be required to register with a designated hospital and report regularly from its compound during the summit.
The regime said it did not intend to turn Beijing Capital International Medical Centre into a media centre, but merely wanted to “ensure the security and comfort of all parties”.
Those who do not abide by the regulation will be off-limits to required services. In the past, the regulations have included bans on soliciting and barring on the capital’s roads as well as banning alcohol, cash donations and red ribbons at the Asean Summit.
NTI Executive Director Octavio de la Viña La-ota told the South China Morning Post the regulations constituted a deliberate constraint to the right of the press to cover the meeting.

Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers are typically more spherical in shape, also they have the ability to contain 200—2,000 Scoville Units. Peppers with up to one million jalapenos can equal one pound.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound effect on the investigation into a local woman’s disappearance and ultimately her murder.
Bill Youngman told lawmakers Wednesday a group of supporters will issue recommendations for proposed legislation and subsequent bills, bills which have be guided by the group’s goal of eradicating violence against women on Indian reservations.
The group is calling for several bills that would increase law enforcement funding, clarify how federal prosecutors handle cases or give family members of missing tribes women more input into police investigations.
“A Native American woman is three time as likely to be a victim of violence and four times as likely to be a victim of sexual violence than a woman of other races,” Youngman told reporters after the meeting.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Compass functions and distance alerts have become standard extensions of GPS navigation aid in some new cars since palm-size devices such as TomTom’s Navigator were widely adopted by consumers in the last decade.
The technology recently rolled out to iPhone smartphones in the U.S.
With the advent of miniaturized GPS electronics, GPS is spreading fast to household amenities people use daily.
With household appliances already on the verge of going Internet-enabled, GPS units will also be put to use inside homes and factories.
Adding GPS to products adds a smarter layer of intelligence, said Jim Salkowitz, co-inventor of the capability.
GPS is already used to help people with severe memory loss who have trouble remembering their childhood homes.
There are similar reports about early adopters fitting GPS fitness sensors.

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of global production.
Foxconn, the world’s largest contract electronics maker, already assembles iPhones in China, Brazil, Mexico and the United States and earlier this month said it had begun trial production of the iPhone SE in India.
Prior to this, the government has signed letters of intent with 15 global handset manufacturers and component makers to produce mobile phones in the country, the official told Reuters.
“Come December, we will see many more handsets - of at least four to five very big brands - hitting the markets, using indigenously manufactured chipsets and completely indigenous assembling,” the official said.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeedMe is a tool that allows high school students to paste a link to their Facebook profiles trusting schools to decide what kind of a student they are.
More than 160 schools already accept the application tool that the 2005 graduates of the University of Virginia and James Madison University founded after discovering Facebook last year. The schools claim to receive tens of thousands of applications using this tool.
So far, ZeeMee has proven to be successful. Colleges feature the test scores, GPA and SAT scores of the applicants after viewing their Facebook profiles and by telling some high school students they increased their chances of acceptance with the tool.

Tonight, the 20-hectoliter production facility will begin the process of turning grain into beer.
Steve Wong, Brewing Operations Manager, and brewer Tim Duggan posed next to a copper vessel that would be the first part of a five-stage process to brew the microbrewery's first batch of Cowabunga IPA this evening.
"We start with a small batch of water," Wong explained while standing next to the vessel. "We put a little oil, sugar and grain in here to kind of get a lid (for chill filtration). Martin Scorsese and Robert Di Niro will collaborate for the first time in decades.
Martin Scorsese's "Silence" may have been his 28-year-old passion project, but it was mostly recently that the famed director settled on the idea of directing a film about Al Capone.
According to The Hollywood Reporter, the pairing will team with producer Emma Koskoff (along with Jon Erlichman of Management 360) to make a feature film about the legendary crime lord. Kim Basinger is in talks to star in the film, but the project is believed to be in the pre-production stage at the moment and the Glendale, Calif. born protagonist is still looking for an actor to play him.
Neither Scorsese nor Di Niro have worked on a project together in over three decades. Their last project was the action-comedy Entrapment (1999).

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1878.
As one of the busiest large radio meteorologists in Concord — if not the busiest — Ray reliably weighs in on the news.
Head south three or four miles from Concord and you reach Lovewell Hill Reservoir in Franklin, powered by the dam you see to the left.
This important drinking water supply for many communities across the region (including a couple that don’t pay up though the Town of Franklin does) is completely full.
But it’s not wet enough here for the storm water basin behind the Union Jack Dam, the body of water created when the Weymouth Falls Paper Company (more about it here) dyed its rivers blue in the 1800s, flooded back in to the present reservoir.
That’s just the beginning of a strange situation clearly underway here, at least looking out over the water.

Q: My great uncle, born in 1874 was the keeper of this bottle which he kept in a curio cabinet in my childhood. It might have belonged to another relative who worked in the china department of a mail order company.
A: Schooners were common sea going vessels used in the days of sailing. Goods and people could travel the world aboard them.
A trials bottle with the words “To the Captain” was sent to the skipper of a ship announcing that the spirit contained in the bottle was of the best quality.
There are twelve writing holes on the bottom side made in the 1800’s so letters could be sent.
Shipping lines issued these schooner “to the Captain” bottles to officers calling on the owners with the assurance that even in the event that the captain fell of the boat during a transfer he would float.
This schooner bottle was a present crated in a dark oak box specially designed to keep spirits at the desired proof.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 170.
An additional $80 billion will be generated in 2002, so to the delight of tax auditors everywhere, the average number of audits is going down.
The impact of the recession and other economic factors have caused the decrease in audits. (Millions people have lost their jobs; fewer small businesses are keeping the books; fewer homes are being sold.) The combination of time, privacy concerns related to backup withholding for non-filers of tax returns, the voluntary disclosure initiative, and other factors have also contributed to the decline in audits.
Workers are more mobile and sales are more global. This has given rise to more people registering late, under-reporting income and other tax frauds. Increased audits take more time and additional resources. The government prefers to spend these resources for verification instead of tax fraud.
IR

I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was an adorable, old victorian home in the center of town with a beautiful, tree lined circular driveway and entry.
This was the spinster’s home I had dreamed of. It was a cottage with the quaintness of a typical New England home. So, when we moved in it was so perfect. The immediate neighborhood had mature trees with bird feeders. The home had wide trees covered in moss. We had fruit trees and roses.
But this utopia had a wrongness. It reminded me of how it felt to come home after a day of searching for a nook or cranny to call my own. It felt as if from years of feeling alone and looking for a small nook, more than looking at it, I had finally found my nook so many years too late.

(Newser) – For less than two weeks, Shelby Carter got to be what she wanted most to be—a mother. Now her friends and family in Wyoming, Ill., are honoring the sacrifice she made to save her credit score and all her finances (and, please, let that be enough). She had her uterus and ovaries removed two days after Christmas, her online fundraiser explains. Her family gathered around as she went into a small hospital suite. She came out a few hours later a 21-year-old "child-free, uterus-free, ovarian-free, healthier for it" woman, the family friend posted this week. Donations have now poured in—nearly enough already to pay back some of the $600,000 in medical bills on her credit score and buy some mommy-related finance things.
More than $200,000 of the gift was donated to Language Law Group, a law firm dedicated to aiding people just like Shelby.

McLeod died in September 2011 after serving half of a five-and-a-half year prison sentence imposed in 2008 after he pleaded guilty to excessive trading and engaging in a fraudulent scheme to pay commissions to himself and others.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and quail at the potential narcissism of the poet who attempts to speak for humanity. In a world of violence, can the tranquility of words and images carry any force? Are they, in the end, nothing more than a luxury that money can no longer afford? Arguably the preeminent anti-war poet and chronicler of the human condition, Galway Kinnell would certainly take issue with such cynicism. When his first collection of poems, Flower Herding on Mount Monadnock, appeared some twenty-five years ago, it was immediately clear that with this collection Kinnell had emerged as a major poetic talent well versed in the rigorous tradition of classical craft yet also burdened with a huge humanism that exposed him to the suffering of the world. This clear-eyed debut won Kinnell a Guggenheim Fellowship and many other accol

Courtesy Redwood City. On Monday, April 9, the city of Redwood City approved an ordinance allowing cannabis business only in the green zone on this map.
Redwood City is open for cannabis businesses.
On Monday, the city Council approved a resolution allowing cannabis business with a retail dispensary license only in the green zone, north of El Camino Real and west of Highway 101.
Those located near El Camino Real can only have a distribution center license wit no cannabis sales, and near Highway 101, only a manufacturing license wit no cannabis sales.
The state Bureau of Cannabis Control developed the guidelines for the zone system in the 2016 Business and Professions Code, which allow licensed adult use cannabis businesses to operate under zoning rules.
According to the resolution, 70 cannabis businesses in the Bay Area are in the draft zone system.
Though the resolution is a step towards allowing cannabis business in the city, there are trips ahead before the first license can be issued in Redwood City.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a European food safety watchdog body said on Thursday.
The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) pesticide unit said that the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) had performed a solid piece of science which concluded that the worldwide use of the chemical over the past several decades does not pose a risk.
The IARC, a committee of the World Health Organisation (WHO), last month labeled glyphosate a "probable human carcinogen".
That classification provoked longstanding complaints from the farm industry that anti-pesticide activists are denying effective products needed to feed the world and earn farmers a living.
A closely watched study tracking the incidence of disease in parts of California where there have been large amounts of agricultural applications of glyphosate was to be published yesterday in the peer-reviewed journal, Environmental Health Perspectives

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who is the third longest tenured news organization executive in the state, announced his plan to retire Feb. 9, about six months after the Pulitzer Prize unexpectedly announced Jim Stratman as managing editor. Soon after the transition, Stratman announced Bunde Schalk as his replacement.
Berthiaume said his decision to retire consists of him returning to his former newspaper roots and following his dream of writing a novel.
"The plan is to write a novel. ... My wife kind of bribed me to retire with the nudge of saying she just really, really wants me to do this. We're touring the castles for about three months and then the contractor and the carpenters get into the house and remodel and I get two years to write the book," Berthiaume said.

Too many potions muddle the alchemy in "The Great Magician," a picaresque romance set around the rivalry between a warlord and a conjurer in 1920s China.
Even in a parochial setting, and despite reverence for ancient wisdom, true wizards are a rare breed. The idiosyncrasies that conjure kismet can also translate into madness (as Regan argues in Paul Auster’s “The Red Notebook,” a matter heard only in the barking of the demon he calls “Horse”). Psychoanalysis aims to restore equilibrium by piercing through the defenses nature cobbles; psychoanalysts, moreover, get paid for the while.
Thomas Mann's "Magic," a novel about the magical career of Otto von Bohm, was filmed in 1948 for (according to Roger Ebert's review, which can be found here) stiffening-the-spine movie preachiness. I can't recommend this version—not one of less sophisticated screenplays.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he was fully aware of the conflict between Plato and Aristotle which we have examined in the present volume [p. 144]. His energies and his abilities were devoted to a mediation between the two philosophical currents. After the break with Christianity, it must be supposed that in the beliefs of Christian theologians, the idea of the eternal de jure divino had already broken free from the Platonizing orientation [p. 74]. With the rise of the powerful Arab intellectual culture, of which the Islam of the Arabic Middle Ages formed an important expressive element, the Jewish religious tradition moved into the lead astray with the idea of dogmatic authoritarianism. Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1986, one of the world’s largest food companies announced a major product recall after a customer complained of cartons of eggs contaminated with fecal matter.
In 2008, a global tire manufacturer modified the casing of one of its tires after a small number of users complained the tires frayed too quickly after being installed.
In 2010, a global confectionary company announced a return policy for a candy bar after a customer complained of biting through the bar.
Things that are common for everyday consumers are no longer ordinary events for large manufacturing companies. KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original Balinese and other Indonesians also fought side-by-side with the Japanese during World War II.
The connection has all but disappeared as have many Balinese people. But the reference remained, a few still speak both languages with a familiar lilt, a language sustained by a small group of elderly people like 91-year-old Amelia Kadari.
Outside a small house, Amelia’s daughter, Eny Sankaersali, welcomes us to the modest dwelling and the woman who remains a bubbling repository of their tales.
“She speaks mostly Japanese,” Eny explains after a while, not referring to her mother’s skills with the language but that Amelia’s English isn’t quite sharp enough to explain the history that still captures everyone’s imagination. She wasn’t just Balinese either but also Bugis, South Sulawesi’s most Karianese language group.

I am compelled to get the word out regarding a Senate bill that could adversely affect private preschools in California. The bill is labeled SB 837 or Kindergarten Readiness Act of 2014.
On the surface, SB 837 looks like a great idea. We all want "kindergarten-ready" kindergartners. But if you read the fine print, you will find that SB 837 is less about kindergarten readiness and more about one of the most devastating threats that could befall our preschool industry.
Under SB 837, the state would dictate the curriculum that all preschools are required to teach. For example, all preschools would be required to include certain types of social studies curriculum and other curricula deemed appropriate by the state. Likewise, kids in preschool would be required to demonstrate certain things on a kindergarten-prep exam.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, sitting en banc, reversed a decision by a three-judge panel last May that the method should not be allowed pending the legal challenge of prisoners Jeffrey Weaver, Willie Johnny Russell and Talmadge Hayes.
Justice Joel Hubner dissented and said the challengers deserve a chance to show they have exhausted ways to avoid the electric chair. They have filed a motion for rehearing en banc.
The Mississippi law, which went into effect on June 30, allows lethal chemicals instead of electrically charged bars to execute death-row inmates.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. People don’t want to open your letter to find out it went to the wrong place.
Receiving an envelope in the mail that has a completely illegible return address will make a prospective recipient think twice about opening the letter, even if it is from a friend or acquaintance. In fact, incorrect return addresses can get your letters and packages returned immediately to the sender without being delivered.
But how do you know exactly how a letter or package should be addressed?
When addressing a letter to a business, follow the three-part format below.
Although the amount of information you include depends on the size of the company, you should always include the proper company name. Jake is a gorgeous, talkative, fun and energetic female blue parakeet looking for a loving guardian.
Jake flew into the backyard of a family in Chicago and landed on a man's shoulder while the man was sitting on the lawn.
The man, who spoke with Jake, said she seemed happy and healthy.
As the family was leaving they realized Jake had been with them the entire time sitting on the man's shoulder so they quickly snapped a picture.
A kind neighbor said the bird did not have a band on and that she had never seen a sick or injured bird do the exact same thing!
It is unique for a stray bird to take a such a positive liking to one person right off the bat.
This is known as a "chimney effect", which occurs when a bird returns to the exact place when becoming distressed to find themselves in the same environment which was previously a safe place where they felt comfortable.
Not only does Jake have a feather missing, there are noticeable bald spots from which she patches with new feathers.
She has short feathered feet

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, the single largest source of the taxes.
Branding himself a “team player” to House Speaker Joe Straus, who isn't cooperating with conservatives’ fiercely fought push to cut property taxes, Abbott insisted that a compromise remain a central goal of the 2015 session. Abbott said he wanted to make lawmakers pass more trade bills, along with a batch of other bills other lawmakers are seeking to pass.
“I want to make sure the session is driven by the resolution we passed — all of it coalescing around tax cuts, moving taxes to a fair and flat rate,” Abbott said when asked if Straus had given a similar promise.
The session is scheduled to begin here Tuesday, with most lawmakers barely had a chance to arrive at the Capitol; rush hour traffic and tornados have partly thwarted the plan.

A memorial service is planned for Fort Bragg City Councilman Jere Melo at 2 p.m. Sept. 10 at the Timberwolf Stadium on Chestnut Street in Fort Bragg.
He died Aug. 24 from complications of a diabetic illness, according to his family.
Melo was born in the Bronx, New York, but after his father was laid off during the 1960s, he moved with his family to Southern California where he attended school at the University of Southern California. He was a standout athlete at Santa Ana College where he earned an Associate's degree in administration of justice.
In 1980, he married Gigi Phelps. They moved to Fort Bragg after he bought FM station KZFR from the original owners, and he moved on to the ABC affiliate, KSRO and KQED, the Bay Area's public television station.
Melo worked in Fort Bragg at KZFR until 2006.
"He was the kind of guy that kept me out of jail so many times!"

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat lung and throat infections such as pneumonia and tonsillitis. It can also treat skin and soft tissue infections, such as cellulitis and wound infections. It can also be used to prevent tonsillitis in children aged 2 months and older when other treatments have failed to prevent infections. Clarithromycin is also available in combination with other medications for the treatment of infections.
Combination medication: Clarithromycin can be combined with other antibiotics in order to increase its effectiveness. The combination medication is also effective in treating bacterial infections.

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, leading to a more acidic ocean with elevated carbon dioxide.
As a result, shell-producing organisms, including plankton and smaller creatures ingested by fish, are less active compared to preindustrial times, according to a new study by Penn State researchers published in Deep Sea Research II: Topical Studies in Oceanography late last month.
This phenomenon is the corrosive equivalent of man-made "chemical warfare" -- yet it's the least problematic effect by far.
The researchers are now working with estheticians to create cosmetics that can remediate the results of this "stony computer." Working with a product known as "Cafilon," a crystalline, gypsum-based resin available in the beauty industry as a skin healing catalyst, the researchers aim to formulate a skin remedy for the chemical burns.

PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the arid figure many expect him to be.
He likes to paint and has a cool house in a leafy suburb south-west of the city.
Meals are taken outside unless a typhoon comes through from the South China Sea.
Higgs isn't uptight.
He isn't intimidated.
He isn't pompous and claims Ukrainian roots.
Higgs is even frugal; a good reason he can take the credit where it's due. Professor Higgs will no doubt be putting the world to rights over the coming days with messages of congratulations from all corners, including Britain's Queen Elizabeth II.
Higgs is fond of posing with picnickers in Edinburgh's Holyrood Park.
Let's have a pint to celebrate. Higgs likes whiskey and he hates nonsense.

"Quanell X called Mahking and stated that he was a licensed attorney" and paid a $500 fee, lawyer Kevin Glasheen said at a news conference to announce the legal action.
Quanell X did not respond to a phone call from KHOU-TV seeking comment on the lawsuit.

Decision made by Agriculture Minister Ariel following Israeli ambassador expulsion from Turkey and Erdoğan statements.
Agriculture Minister Uri Ariel ordered freezing import of agricultural produce from Turkey to Israel this afternoon, days after Turkey deported Israeli ambassador after Gaza flotilla attack and admission of blockading the coast. "Due to the unacceptable grandstanding by the Turkish leadership," wrote Ariel, "my instruction is to stop the importing of Turkish agricultural produce after the end of the season."
As the season is now prematurely ending the move will have limited impact and will not prevent Turkish produce from being reintroduced if Turkey changes track.
The Turkish decision to expel the ambassador from Ankara came after Israel had announced it would block the Turkish flotilla. Some 200,000 tons of Turkish agricultural produce are imported annually – mainly fruits, vegetables and a small amount of grain. According to the Migdal insurance company the volume of business translated into a profit of some 300 million shekels ($80 million) to the insurer last year.

HELENA, Mont. — U.S. Rep. Greg Gianforte is pinning his third campaign in two years on Montana residents being better off economically since President Donald Trump took office and that the voters will give him a third term in November.
The three-term Montana Republican filed paperwork last week with the Federal Election Commission to run for re-election, which allows him for the first time to rake in campaign dollars and travel to campaign events.
“I’m grateful for the patients my opponents have demonstrated and the fact they haven't called for a primary to make the campaign season more divisive,” Gianforte’s spokesman Brice Bennett said in an interview with Montana Public Radio.
Gianforte isn’t facing a competitive primary election. None of his GOP colleagues have announced a primary challenge and multiple reports have speculated any announced GOP candidates are long shots against the incumbent.

A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide because of it.
So how has it gone viral?
Facebook | FacebookNews
Facebook users should be on the alert for a new malware hoax making the rounds on the popular social network.
The bogus connection employs a charm offensive by a young girl who claims to be suicidal because Facebook has slapped a virus on her.
Hoodwinked into clicking on the link to see a cute, sad-eyed picture of the girl, many Facebook users have been swindled by the virus, passing it along to friends indiscriminately.

McChord, who started the online security company Datto in 2007 in his father's basement, will step down as CEO.
McChord, who started the online security company in 2007 in his father's basement, said he wanted to spend more time with his family and on personal projects.
"After more than a decade as CEO at Datto, I am taking the time this year to reflect and further define my own role in the industry and also serve my community through board service at a number of organizations I strongly support, Better Business Bureau (GBB), Special Olympics and a past board member at Templeton Collegiate School," McChord said in a statement.
Datto was one the best-performing stocks on IPO hub Nasdaq this year.
McChord also co-founded the Bainbridge Graduate Institute, which addresses sustainability and environmental concerns through curriculum in entrepreneurship and social impact, with Duke Bradford, a former director at PetSmart. The school merged with Presidio Graduate School, of San Francisco, in 2010.

NBN Co expects to have reached a deal to resign its $11.2 billion definitive agreements with Telstra by the end of the year, with the network access agreement (NAA) signed early next year, according to the NBN Co’s chief executive Mike Quigley.
NBN Co is required under the Telecommunications Act to renegotiate the agreements which detail how Telstra, the former monopoly telecommunications company, delivers its network to the telco. NBN Co was established under the Act to build, own and operate a nationwide telecommunications network.
NBN Co and Telstra formalised their landmark agreement, which required the telco to help roll out the NBN throughout Australia by the end of 2020. It also resulted in NBN Co paying Telstra $12 billion for copper, HFC (hybrid fibre coaxial cable) and other assets required to build the network, and $3 billion more if the network remains below 63 per cent of households by 2018.

Edinburgh's Hogmanay kicks off very soon - here's everything you need to know about the end of year celebration.
When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the Saturday before New Year's Eve (which is a Monday), so if you've seen it take place on the Sunday, don't worry, you've seen the right thing.
In 2018 the procession will take place on Saturday 30 December.
The procession set off from the Meadows, making its way to George Square (and will continue on the same route), so you can catch all the action around the side of the Art School, the Botanic Gardens' Inverleith House and can get a a brilliant view of the procession leaving the Meadows on North Prestonfield Road.
After the procession moves outside of the city the route takes in the open park area next to Edinburgh Zoo, and the procession ends up outside the Scott Monument – with all the torches stopping together at a drum circle.

Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and eventually faced the execution order, is one of the most widely revered men of the 20th century. For the church, he represents a forerunner of the theologians who so compellingly nuanced the theology of liberation in the 1970s and 1980s and an antidote to the church’s widespread moral and theological apathy. The Michigan Chapter of the Antique and Classic Boat Society had nearly 200 boats lined up in the Black River between Seventh and 10th streets. The previous record for an ACBS International Boat Show was 170 boats.
A camera drone swirled the boats in final preparation for the show.
Boats sat alongside the Lootens Dock on the canalside above the Riverwalk.
Many boats were poised along the river with the City Historic District in the background.
Riverwalk visitors walked around the birchbark canoe, a passenger canoe at Fargo House and a swingboat, the latest vessel coming to the Black River.
More than 20 passenger canoes, cruisers and a timberboat – the Glidden Dream – were moored for visitors’ viewing along the Riverwalk.
Some pristine classics were docked near the Black River Collegiate School for visitors to admire as they walked to the show.
Dozens of wooden craft were docked at Lootens Dock.
A steam tug made its way down the Black River.

One of the United States' most important defense alliances may be unraveled or reoriented by President-elect Donald Trump after he takes office, based on past critical comments and coalition-member fears.
Trump's rhetoric has repeatedly chaffed NATO members into questioning the dynamic of the 28-year-old military alliance, where members have committed to collective defense of the entire alliance.
"If you look at what we do for NATO and what we get, it's unfair," Trump said during a rally speech earlier this year in Iowa. "They [NATO countries] aren't paying their fair share; you know the countries are not paying their fair share.
On the campaign trail in Scotland, Trump condemned NATO for its lack of defense spending under America's leadership.

Christian formation is the lifelong process of growing in our relationship with God, self, others, and all creation. Every experience in our lives can provide us with the opportunity to express our faith; the challenge we face is recognizing these opportunities. Our lives are really wrapped up in the rich mysteries of creation and human experience, and these invite us into a lifelong journey of discovery and learning. Being a Christian is a whole way of life, and it can't be fully explained in a classroom or a worship setting.
Christian formation invites us into a covenantal relationship with God. It is a companionable, life-long process of living in a timeless, trusting relationship with God. This experience provides us with the opportunity to experience the infinite mystery of God’s presence through the full variety of human experiences.
We seek to create a Christian Identity in children, youth, and adults through the three basic stages of life: birth, death, and resurrection. CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abdul Latif, a columnist for the luxury borders outdoor magazine Information Age, was taken into custody after publishing a book online calling for the replacement of decades-old subsidy policies.
His wife, Amira Abdul Latif, who is also the author's lawyer, told Reuters he had been taken to a local police station in downtown Cairo after being summoned for questioning twice in recent days.
She did not know if the reason for his detention was a Facebook page he had set up that translated some of the author's economic philosophies into Arabic.
“On May 5 he was called by two guys at the journalism faculty ... at Cairo University with a warrant for the arrest of Slim Ahmed for publishing false news in the country. It is a serious charge,” she said.

he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon–and other metalloids and metals–to move rapidly from atoms in the "subsurface" to those at the surface. In fact, the inner core of the silicon transistor is a traveling wave in the subsurface of the "transistors" (above a junction of two separate semiconducting materials, one p−type). Understanding the subsurface movement of electrons is therefore a key to a visualization of the broad present and future applications of the Si chip. Its ubiquitous presence has created the analogy of "electron moving electron" in the "smart phone" (CPU, phone memory, etc.) all organized hierarchically like atoms in the subsurface. Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what you can offer. Here are seven effective ways to prepare for an interview question like this.
Employers want to know motivated applicants will contribute to the success of the organization. Gather information about the company during your interview preparation. Find out the company mission statement, along with its objectives, goals, and overall vision. Describe how you can develop as a professional and contribute to the achievement of the company's objectives.
Hiring managers want successful candidates who can think outside the box and solve problems. Describe how your skills have enabled you to solve problems in the past. This is also a chance to talk about your objectivity and how you can work with a diverse group. Discuss how you can handle weaknesses, such as becoming bored or falling behind when you have trouble seeing the big picture. Give examples demonstrating how you handled a challenging situation during a project or an experience

A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an Ormond Beach police official said Tuesday.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York City train hit the construction equipment around 2 a.m. outside the duo Bridges project in the Grove Hall neighborhood of Boston, said Lisa DeJaco, a spokeswoman for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The construction equipment was off the track and diverted equipment on the street, DeJaco said
Emergency vehicles could be seen on the side of the tracks off the elevated Orange Line subway platform, near UMass Boston. News photographers reported heavy green tarps on the railway tracks.
A fire official said a joy craft was the vehicle struck by the train, and the worker who apparently died worked for the Amtrak contractor. Amtrak spokesman Sean Joyce said the victim had been with the railroad for more than a decade and appeared to have suffered a heart attack after the impact of the train hitting the equipment.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 9 margin late Thursday, sending the proposal to Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper’s desk for his decision. Democrats hold a strong majority in the state House and Senate, which means the bill is expected to be signed.
Called House Bill 1280, the legislation allows marijuana businesses to pay some of their state taxes with their cannabis, as opposed to the cash-only model upon which most drug businesses currently operate.
Some distributors have already found creative ways to skirt the state’s cash-only policy, a move the state backers hopes improves legal weed’s appearance — and the perception that the substance is doing more harm than legal drug stores — with taxes paid by electronic means.

TEN couples in Cagayan de Oro City finally tied the knot in front of the altar last Saturday, March 23, during the mass wedding rites held at St. Augustine Cathedral, this morning. Sixteen TEN singles, including four priests and one nun, have already expressed intention to marry.
An annual activity of the program TEN (Through Education, the Nation), allegedly the world’s first televised nondenominational study program for everyday people, the mass wedding rites is also a large-scale typical Filipino celebration of the institution of matrimony.
During the event, participants are reminded how they can continue improving their relations with God, as well as with family and friends, through their faith and diligence.
CDO PIO Head Joel Lucas discussed the event with the priests who attended the wedding ceremony.
TEN celebrates its Kagay-anon stations’ 2nd year anniversary on April 10 with a walk-for-life event at the Cagsawa Ruins in Daraga, Albay. Last April 2013

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to get out from under a pile of debt can be just as difficult. Learning how to get out of debt (or not acquiring it in the first place), should be a goal for every one of us. Here are a few tips on how to deal with credit cards if you or a loved one is in over their head.
Before making any big decisions, you have to have a plan of action. A good rule of thumb is to only charge what you can pay off in one payment, and never carry a balance from one month to the next. If this means you are going to have to make sacrifices, so be it. Take a second job or cut as many expenses as you can out of your monthly budget. Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor.
The results are undeniable. Tenants with the means to do so have made the decision to live in San Francisco, while residents with more modest means have moved elsewhere.
The percentage of the population living below the poverty level climbed from 9.9 percent in the 1970 census to 15.3 percent in the latest one.
In the last decade, especially, the biggest growth in the ranks of the poor has been among families with more than one kid. From 1999 to the most recent tax records, the number of families earning below the 200 percent poverty level more than doubled and are now 50 percent of San Francisco’s estimated 204,100.

Experts at the organization - who duly added the bottle to their collection of more than 600 - said that if nothing went wrong with normal PostNL mail, it had taken the billed 8-10 weeks to reach Kampen.

The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA). The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The Narromine Garden Club have gifted their annual donation to local organisation the Narromine Volunteer Rescue Association (VRA).
The club gathered at the Narromine VRA headquarters on December 5 to hand over a cheque for almost $1000.
The group have made the donation for the past six years, making a total of just under $6000.
The Narromine Garden Club have a long history with the Narromine VRA, with the vice president Debbie Jackson’s husband Ian also a member.
Narromine Garden Club Committee Secretary Virginia Morgan said the group originally decided to make the donation to the local rescue services after the Babadong bushfire.
As well as a monetary donation, the garden club also donates garden beds filled with native trees, shrubs and flowers each year.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their own servers, many smaller providers only have a limited number of servers to rent server space to clients. This means they rent interior server space to people looking for web hosting services.
People can save a substantial amount of money when purchasing web servers directly from a large site rather than going through a reseller as a middleman. However, some find it harder to deal with a large company directly, and prefer to have a reseller act as the intermediary. By cutting out some of the middleman expenses, a reseller can earn a much smaller cut than the actual hosting web site. This means more money saved for the client, and more profit for the reseller.
Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not survive the first 28 days after birth – decreased from 6.67 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2000 to 5.16 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2010, a 23% reduction.
But that improvement levled out in the last few years with a six-year average of 5.20 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2007-12, compared to 5.10 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in 2013-17.
The reasons for this increase are unclear, the study authors reported, but could be attributed to increasing maternal age
