The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite North Carolina’s renewable-energy goal.
Under the three-year program, the Utility Commission can purchase clean energy from a certain kind of renewable energy certification.
During the same time frame, the Commission also can purchase power from a town or county wind farm, a senior living community, an apartment complex, zero-emissions military facilities or new privately owned solar facilities in the Tar Heel state.
“These are the places where you will have the greatest impact in the shortest period of time,” said James Kibirat, senior policy adviser for renewable energy with the N.C. Department of Environmental Quality.

MGM Resorts International (MGM), the largest casino and hotel operator on the Las Vegas Strip, is looking for a rebound in the famed gambling resort.
MGM’s Vegas properties include casino giants like the Bellagio, the iconic ‘Welcome to Fabulous Vegas’ sign, and the Venetian.
The news comes after Japanese casino giant Sony announced they are looking into buying a casino resort.
After the coronavirus drastically shuttered brick-and-mortar casinos in the country, Sony Entertainment Communications America Inc., a Japanese entertainment company, subleased its location on the Las Vegas Strip for $1.2 million, a move that some analysts suggest may eventually make their way to the gaming hub.
Sony later announced its surprise acquisition of the facility.
“I believe the casino license gives the corporation the legality and practicality to operate a casino in the US and the transaction will consolidate the corporation’s casino business,” Sony Group Executive Vice President Ikki Kishita told local Japanese media last week.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as fibroblasts appear to work together to send a signal to the micro-environment around a cell to limit the growth or damage of genetic changes to the DNA.
The discovery — made using live fur-coated adult elephants, excised kidney and heart cells from a deceased elephant, and engineered human skin fibroblast cells — could help humans with cancer use drugs called senescent cells to block their cells from rapidly replicating themselves.
That could trick the body into regulating the cells, slow their growth and prevent the mitotic stage of reproducing into a cell that can spread in the body, Johns Hopkins Medicine said in a statement.
In humans with neo-plastic cancers, there can be up to 300 mitotic stages happening at once.
The study authors compared the elephant justice mechanism with the way a common household bleach helps control infestations.

More than 400 convictions of jail inmates tied to strip-searches should be reviewed, the private, for-profit National Forensic Consulting group said after a review of thousands of cases. Of those, it believes about 100 defendants had their convictions thrown out because the former state chemist blew the tests she conducted in the first place.
It also estimates more than 600 prosecutions linked to the former chemist’s previous roles with a private testing agency and the Suffolk district attorney’s office. The reviewers had previously estimated about 300 earlier prosecutions were suspect, after a review of thousands of cases linked to her.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the University of California, Los Angeles, examined the impact of yoga on eight people with high anxiety — an average of 7 on the Mental Health Inventory scale. The yoga poses (such as child pose and trikonasana) were chosen according to the tradition and the poses’ effects on organs and emotions. The twice-weekly 60-minute sessions also involved meditation (descending the breath Counts, Cycle of the Seasons) and a ritual to center the self (breath and mandala constructions). Researchers trained the medical students and teachers who provided feedback about poses, meditation, and other ritual activities.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look at the emissions profile of the 200 biggest S&P/ASX200 companies – more than half (112) of which have an emissions intensity above the Paris Agreement of 55 grams of carbon dioxide per dollar of revenue.
Of those, the 10 companies with the highest emissions intensities – the 12 with the worst emissions ratios – are all mining companies, representing just under a quarter of the share of energy mining assets in the index. Together they have emissions intensities averaging 94 grams of CO2 per dollar of revenue – almost twice the intensity target mandated under PM Scott Morrison’s own 2050 emissions reduction target.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by Sir Hugh AC, returned to England. Their ships were carried southwards on ice floes, and came close to the voyage's objective, the mouth of the river that today bears their name, the Chany. The next chart is from 1656, when least squares linear regressions were used to estimate the general movement of sea ice in the Arctic region. These projections were apparently the product of German scientists for they are labelled as Die Abir vis seine Nord Poli in den aDischen Anexthren. Also present are charts from the 1720s, and later, more more historically step lines to represent the edge of freeze-up. This simple line represented the corner of the ice-covered area. Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a hot issue. And using compost as mulch is one of the time-tested, no-brainer ways to get your yard to look its best immediately.
One of the needs most commonly neglected in the spirit of saving time and money is getting our beds ready for spring. Adding compost to the bed not only improves the texture and drainage, but also provides the growing medium that holds onto soaks and feeds the young roots of plants for some time to come. Compost is a potent aid to raising vigorous, nourished soybeans and other crops.
Although the evidence speaks for itself, some consumers new to composting have questions about both the safety and the efficacy of the product. We will talk about the safety in the moment, but should begin with the efficacy of the product.

“Today, we are recognizing a few remarkable acting performers, people who, despite their own challenges, have done outstanding work to combat the prejudice and isolation that can so often come from mental illness,” the president said in the opening remarks of the White House Conference on Data and Accountability in Mental Health.
The discussion followed the mass shooting and suicides at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut a year ago – which Obama called the “worst day” of his presidency – and included members of the Biden’s Task Force on Gun Violence Prevention.

It takes a lot to make me feel ashamed of London, my beloved home city. But yesterday’s tower-block inferno did it. The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing image of people leaping 11 storeys into the night sky, the casual tales of people charging with their bags through the smoke — all this should have been a huge collective scandal resulting in collective politicalfallout.
And the political fallout is indeed taking place. Mr May’s hands are trembling at the thought that this will permanently jeopardise her moment of political ascendancy – after the knife attacks, terror attacks, and the budget woe – with the elections a mere five months away. And once it became clear that the whole grim fracas resulted not from a freak accident but from a dodgy refurbishment (at a cost of £10 million) no longer permitted under the law due to its flammability, the pressure was huge to get action and justice.

Some history
Thomas Jefferson wrote about Revere's ride to the Massachusetts colonists resistance, being the inspiration for the town meeting he had attended a week earlier.
George Gile wrote it was the ride that "first induced the inhabitants of the surrounding villages to turn out on the morning of the 19th, and descend to the town-house to meet with their brethren from the interior. But the absence of more than a thousand men recalled [the other] three into the interior of the town; and there waited the result of what had been already effected, the moon shining the whole time, till about ten o'clock, when she could shine no more on that decisive scene."

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control announcing an end to the program. Regulators said it was deceptive to call a distillery and order a mixed drink when such a transaction cannot take place, so the agency ordered state-licensed businesses to close the practice Tuesday.
A handful of other states allow distilleries to make cocktails for immediate consumption — California has the most at 55, according to a 2018 study published by the Wall Street Journal — but the number of distilleries participating is limited.
That's the case in Alaska, too, where three craft distillers currently operate; no other mixed drink establishments were on the list of licensed bar or restaurant establishments that could have made more than 20 mixed drinks to be sold as commemorative souvenirs.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter Maya.
Karnow's acclaimed work on Vietnam, "Very Long War," won a National Book Award in the hybrid category more than 30 years ago.
Meticulously compiled in Air Force One during the time President Richard Nixon divided the conflict and Karnow worked for the Associated Press on the Paris peace accords, Karnow found in the work a way into history.
"To the extent history is a meaningful record of the human condition, we have a duty to communicate it to those after us," Karnow wrote on the back flap of the paperback edition of "Very Long War." "Those who fail history condemn the world to its repetition."

A report by the Wall Street Journal suggests that Dell could be on the verge of becoming a public company once again.
The deal could be announced as soon as later today and -- if the cited sources close to Dell are correct -- the $25 billion sale would slash Dell's debt by half.
The once-revered PC and server maker became a private entity in September of 2013 when it went public with a $25 billion, special dividend buyout. The creation of the new company meant the removal of all public shareholders.
Dell reported revenues of $58.8 billion-$60.7 billion for 2018.
The deal is reportedly valued at some $21 billion plus its $10 billion cash on hand. The sale price would slash the company's debt from more than $40 billion in total.
Dell announced earlier that it will cancel its fourth quarter earnings call due to the potential deal.

Heavy rain hammered Connecticut during Monday morning’s commute, causing spinouts and a roof collapse, while wind and flooding may lie ahead.
The sun was shining brightly in Hartford by late morning, only to go dark as the sky opened up around Turnpike Exit 33 just a few miles away from the capital as the remains of Hurricane Henri continued to push through the southwestern part of the state.
No one was injured in the roof collapse around 6:40 a.m. at the Valero gas station on Roosevelt Drive, said Detective Captain Barry Dennerly with the Moosup, Conn. Police Department.
Here’s how closures and traffic patterns were changing around the state during the morning commute.
The stretch of Interstate 95 southbound from exit 58 to the Delaware border was closed Monday morning with vehicles diverted to Interstate 295 southbound.
The ramps from Interstate 95 northbound and southbound from exits 61 to 4 in Wethersfield were closed Monday as well, the state Department of Transportation said.

The teen’s mother Elly Fautz says the school is making a real difference in the life of a grieving community.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify the potential impact of the options they have with a task. The diagram shows the consequences of a decision – the probability of the decisions' outcomes, while the costs are mapped as a branch that leads off the decision tree. A well-constructed decision tree allows a decision maker to assess scenarios, such as the impact of purchasing a new manufacturing tool.
Decision trees graphs can evaluate the costs and consequences of various types of outcomes and allow decision-makers to see the impact various management styles have on the options a project manager considers when choosing to take a risk. A decision tree can help show the cost-saving impact it could have if the firm implements an operational risk management plan. This allows the decision-maker to reflect on the recent litigation the firm had experienced and how having the new operational risk management plan would have helped with the litigation and the organization's reputation.

A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon (0500 GMT) on Saturday after heavy rainfall, according to Sama Le Min Min, a local official.
At least a dozen people are feared buried – including a Jackson Mayit, a photographer caught in the landslide with his brother, Khet Mayit, a miner.
Yangbay Lawu, 45, said the men had trekked down the mountainside to collect jade quartz, a form of the gemstone prized in China and around the world.
"Around 7 pm (1200 GMT), a rocklide poured down the mine after the rain in the evening," Lawu, standing in a stream of black water in the aftermath with clothes ripped off and arms cuffed to her waist with dirty green rope, told AFP Sunday.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier movie festival in the southern port city of Busan.
Entitled "Deliver Us From Evil", the 100-minute film wows audiences with a dark and violent take on a budding matchmaking scene involving the precariat - a newly created class of people outside the protection offered by both tradition and law.
Rather than rehash the struggles of the working sub-classes of other Asian societies, director Park Dae-yeon frames these men and women as victims of a predatory marketplace made up of everything from matchmaking scams to fake HIV tests.
Without overstating the case, the film powerfully captures the sullen world of working people left with little recourse.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp.

This is the first of two major announcements I am making this week.
Now that the dust has settled from last month’s Many Gods West conference for polytheists, I have divined and listened and decided that YES, Many Gods Papers are happening.
I have invited people who are all wildly diverse about what Polytheist means and how it applies to their (and my own) own theological thoughts. Their proposals are respectful, profound, informative, innovative, and many other things. I wanted to have a place where people could make a ‘paper’ -a smaller independent project I can see.
There is no strict agenda other than to have something freaking awesome to read. A few projects have been turned down and others have been accepted to be turned into books one day. But the plan is to have a wide range diverse works and see where it takes us.
This initiative is independent, independent – not connected to the Many Gods West conference. (Unless people want it to be.) We can consider it independent, other people calling themselves ‘Pagan Polytheists’ or other fiefdoms can call us whatever they choose.

A Canton-based food pantry that feeds hundreds of families across western Wayne County is getting a boost as it heads toward the Thanksgiving holiday.

more produce with volunteers serving soup, french fries, cucumbers and locally
made farm salad for the guests.
Now, donor dollars have doubled this year
for the Open Door ministry. People can donate by sending checks earmarked for the
Food Ministry.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
A study published earlier this year by the same research group discovered a strong link between so-called "warm grandmothers" — women with more positive maternal relationship with their granddaughters — and less fighting with their grandchildren.
Grandmothers are more unusual now than they have traditionally been. As fewer people move away after marriage, have children and raise a large family, there are fewer matrilineal grandmothers around than there once were. This situation has resulted in some challenges when it comes to family relationships among grandparents and grandchildren, with both groups sometimes having a difficult time adjusting to the absence of the nuclear family.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a quickened pace during the month of March.
A gain in equities, with financial shares aiding the advance, curbed data-driven demand for Treasurys. Tracking the 20-year Treasury yield, the government debt market has shed more than a quarter-percent from the highs set just two sessions ago, though it remains further into the upside than downside so far this year after factoring in a muted start to 2013.
“Pickups [from data] can always be a cause of some concern on the [longer] end of the curve. Even if it’s a minor move,” said Jack Kconigion, vice president and trader at Milford Asset Management, who sees the treasury curve shifting into a flattening trend, as yields on the short and intermediate ends rise while the long end yields come in.

There is possibly no other figure in Scottish history greater worshipped than Robert the Bruce.
Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his return to the Scottish throne in 1320, King Robert is celebrated across the country with tales of valour and personal sacrifice from battles as far apart as Bannockburn (June 1314) and his eventual overthrowing of the English invasion at nearby Battle of Halidon Hill (22nd July 1333).
And yet with this legacy of history laying across the Kingdom of Alternating Festivals and Piping, an equally vast legacy lies buried beneath the modern history of antiquated scorn the entire world over knows as the Battle of Bannockburn Centre. Sitting at the east gate of the ruined Stirling Castle, the 50 year old museum is a historical upheaval.

Lyft has pulled from service all of its on-demand electric bicycles in New York, Washington DC and the San Francisco Bay area after some riders reported issues with the brakes.
"We recently received a small number of reports from riders about some on-demand electric bicycles malfunctioning," a Lyft spokesperson confirmed after publication. "Out of an abundance of caution, we are providing full refunds to these riders and have temporarily paused these vehicles from being available on the ride with the Lyft app in NYC, the Bay area and the DC area. We are working with the bicycle manufacturer to support a thorough investigation surrounding this issue."
As with another recent braking issue that impacted a different electric bike manufacturer, the bikes in question have had a mechanical "coasting" and "loading brake" system built into the frame, reports Bloomberg. The system is designed to make it easier to start riding the bikes without pedaling them and also to compensate for inertia. The issue occurs when the braking system gets involved during loading or coasting situations, according to the report.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered it, just hours after a separate journalist was killed in the key western state of Michoacan.
Police said the gang responsible for Mónica Campuzano’s murder had tried to lure her to meetings to try to buy drugs on the pretext that they wanted to write about her paper.
Imperial Vice Prosecutor Carlos Nava Vega said the investigation into the Sept. 1 killings was still too preliminary to offer more details, but that numbers used in cellphone messages suggest the group had expected 100 employees a week to buy drugs from them.
Human rights workers have expressed concerns that organized crime groups are gaining greater control over more territory — and more people — in some regions of Mexico.

Remember Microsoft's Bing Cashback program, which refunded a few percentage points (and sometimes more than a few) of online purchases made via the Bing portal? Microsoft shuttered the program last June, but its ad partner (the one that also offers Target exclusives) hasn't let the concept die quite yet. Here's Google Shopping Express: Get a flat-out price reduction for an order, and then get a some cash back for purchases made afterward: a coupon code with a number between zero to $2000.
As Google tells it (without offering a detailed explanation), the promotion will be offered semimonthly during the next month on particular products, and appears during your shopping routine on the Dropline page (and across Google Express properties). There are common offer types on the Dropline landing page, and Google is not sharing the criteria necessary to trigger these offers. Google also says that a single Dropline offer can have offer codes associated with it.

Gene Blevins/ReutersA tornado in Kansas last week. A new poll suggests the public feels that global warming is real.
Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are six important things to know about the history of the event.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day, an environmental teach-in at college campuses across the country, on April 22, 1970.
The purpose was to force Americans to focus on their effects on the earth: "We rob the Earth first, and then compound the violence by robbing the Solar system, the Milky Way Galaxy, the entire universe and all the time wonder why the Earth doesn't see us one more year."
The celebration was immediately popular, and soon after Congress established the Environmental Protection Agency.
A 2009 Gallup poll said 859 Americans believe global warming to be a real scientific fact.
The San Francisco Chronicle labeled the celebration we all know and love a "corporate creation," pointing to their fact that corporate sponsorship was worth millions.
That label

The security vendor Avast has received a $100m investment from private equity firm Summit Partners, in exchange for a minority stake in the company.
Avast chief executive Vince Steckler described the move as a “significant milestone” and a “major financial achievement for Avast” of more than 900 employees across the globe.
“As we expand rapidly into new and emerging markets, continue innovating core security solutions, and launch into new technologies and services in corporate cybersecurity, the funding from Summit Partners will enable us to continue investing in great talent and our corporate ecosystem of ISVs, OEMs and channel partners,” he said. “With this investment, we will be able to accelerate the pace at which security needs are met globally, increasing our impact on people’s lives and our reach as a global security player.”
Summit Partners vice president Nikhil Basu Trivedi added it was ”impressed with the innovation and transparency made possible by the key open source contributor and trust-driven model Avast provides”.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might time and time again make them fail.
It is often these rules that will dictate your exits as well.
Most traders, when they start out, have no idea what things are going to think they are going to time in a certain way. Or they are going to happen a certain way. So what are some of the general rules?
News Release – Never trade into a news release with more than 15 minutes left, if they have trouble predicting a worldwide unemployment projectable, what chance do you have at forecasting currency trends?
Counter Trend – If the news is a surprise (ie unemployment, inflation or CPI) go STOP

Facebook's new Home software on Android means still more ways to interact with people whom you're not actually with at the time. Is that always a good thing?
If you're one of the people who get Facebook's new Home on your HTC phone, you'll undoubtedly get some questions from your friends. The Wall likes to call the bunch of people on your Facebook friends list your "casual network." But that's the wrong name for what your phone's "casual network" actually is.
As I explain in my Matrix-related review, Facebook Home tethers your Facebook contacts to your phone so you can display their Facebook updates on your homescreen. It also provides a sidebar with buttons you can tap to quickly post updates or tag friends in your photos.
As you use the feature for a couple of minutes you start to realize how helpful it can be. But if you can accept a substitution you can make that makes your homescreen more personal at the expense of a bit of functionality, you don't have to accept Facebook's big promo of your People-ness and your Facebook-ness.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to the national security establishment, did not say in its report how many advanced centrifuges were enriching uranium. The report comes after an agreement between the U.S. and Iran to win back its nuclear commitments crumbled over the weekend.
Western powers feared Iran’s nuclear program could be instrumental in helping the Islamic Republic to someday develop atomic weapons. Iran says its program is meant only for peaceful purposes and that it has terminated nuclear weapons work.
Uranium enriched at a low level is used to make reactor fuel — Iran already enriches uranium up to 20% — but uranium enriched toaround 90% is needed to maintain a nuclear bomb.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating a boardroom struggle for control. The Swiss mobile operator announced the proposed extension on Monday along with a deal to buy smaller rival Salt's fiber assets.
Sunrise, backed by wealthy representatives of the Zumtaugwald clan, plans to vie for Swisscom , the country's largest telecoms operator.
On Monday, the family's head Gualtiero Zumtaugwald called the extension an unnecessary burden on a business that had a strong momentum and was not in agreement with how its board ceased power.
"We require an extended information period in order to review the consequences of the plans detailed in the Sunrise Capital announcement," he wrote in a letter addressed to the board of directors.
The decision over the capital plan was made late in the evening of March 29 and "completely contradicted the mandate given by the general meeting", he wrote.

In addition to a sense of adornment or function, clothing can provide insights to global issues like the economy and climate change.
TANG UNCOVERS FASHION: With her new book “Disrobed: How Clothes Lie and Why We Wear Them” (Riverhead Books), the Bloomsburg University sociologist Angela Y. Davis looks for food in the fashions of those who survive in a capitalist system.
Davis said the ways people treat their clothes often says more about the messages we take from the world than the shoes and jackets themselves.
“Clothing provides a powerful method of communication that delivers measurements of the history, economics, gender roles, religion and ideology of the people who make and own it,” Davis wrote in her book.
The clothing of those stranded on the Brooklyn side of the Manhattan bridge in 2003 showed more of their circumstances than the economic system they lived in, she said.
Their clothing also said a great deal about the New York (and national) political system they lived in.

Star Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas, 28, appeared in the D.C. Superior Court to be sentenced for the gun crime he admitted to in January. He has been spared a jail term.
In January this year, Arenas admitted that he illegally brought a unloaded automatic weapon with hollow points into the Verizon Center – a gun which he accidentally discharged.
The maximum sentence for carrying a pistol with no license is a year in jail.
Gilbert Arenas managed to avoid jail time by receiving probation and “vertical probation,” which means he will be required by the judge tosubmit himself to random searches by National Basketball Association (NBA) security people at all the facilities until the conclusion of the NBA season next March.
The ruling also obliges him to spend 280 hours performing community service with children and the elderly, take anger management, drug and alcohol counseling sessions.
The gun was either left behind in a taxi or at his suburban home after he had played a late-night basketball game earlier.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire consisted of 12 multiple-choice questions, and those who answered seven or less correctly were deemed to have a ‘below basic’ knowledge of the subject.
Only 13% of Americans were deemed ‘proficient’ in the survey, meaning they answered at most three of the questions incorrectly. Another 25% of respondents had a ‘basic’ knowledge of the subject and 28% had a ‘low’ level of scientific knowledge; answering five or fewer questions correctly fell under this category. 20% of Americans surveyed had a ‘very poor’ scientific knowledge and those who answered all 12 questions incorrectly made up a whopping 9% of the sample size.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had departed Seattle around noon Pacific time and was due to arrive in Los Angeles at 6 p.m. Pacific time.
Instead, the crew was required to return to the airport after a baggage handler and airport employee left the cargo hold unattended around 2:30 p.m. local time, the airline said in a tweet.
Alaska Airlines confirmed the passenger was not located and the flight had been canceled.
The airline said the baggage handler was located by airport authorities personnel and is cooperating with a police investigation into the incident.
The airline did not identify the crew member, passenger or location of the flight.
Reports indicated the flight was bound for San Jose, California.
The incident is not the first time an airport worker has taken a nap in restricted airside areas and left a passenger trapped.

ROCK CREEK -- From calling in Craig Robinson to host the Hollywood-themed 20th annual gala this Saturday, to implementing a new strategic plan, the Washington County Museum is exploring all avenues in a time of transition.
"It's all about taking the buckled shoes off and looking inside and figuring out who the heck are we? Who are we as a museum? Will we have a grandparents room? Will we have a junior ranger room? Will we have a international section? Will we have a local history exhibit?" Executive Director Amber Fehlner said during a half-day retreat at Rock Creek Community Park last week.
Fehlner hopes the museum, which has a staff of eight and an annual operating budget of $800,000, can reach out to partner with other organizations and advance its mission of collecting, preserving and exhibiting artifacts of Washington County history and the imprint of its cultural mix.
"We will not survive if Washington County doesn't survive," Fehlner said. "I think the county needs us just as much as the community needs us."

In Sudan, the head of the newly installed military council resigned Friday, just one day after he was sworn in following the ouster of autocrat President Omar al-Bashir. Army deputy chief of staff General Mohammed Hamdan, also known as Hemedti, replaced Abdel Fatta Ahmed al-Burhan as the military council chief. Hemedti is a close ally of al-Bashir and ran spoiler campaigns in the 2015 referendum to join Sudan with the South Sudan through a specially endorsed referendum in the capital. A previous deal between the military leadership and protesters also included the transition of power from al-Bashir to a joint civilian and military council last week. The protesters had demanded the removal of the military leadership from their transition plan.

Insight: Did Conficker help sabotage Iran's nuke program?
(Reuters) - A cyber warfare expert claims he has linked the Stuxnet computer virus that attacked Iran’s nuclear program in 2009 to a cat-and-mouse battle in the Internet with a group of hackers called Conficker, using the code name “Kaspersky” - believed to be a nod to the Russian antivirus firm founded by Dr. Eugene Kaspersky.
Alexey E. Tsarev – a 28 year old Russian-American who owns the website www.itsecuritylab.com – told Reuters the Conficker group had collaborated with the United States and its allies to sabotage the Islamic Republic’s uranium enrichment activities.
But Kaspersky, whose antivirus products are increasingly used by corporate and government customers, declined to comment on the conversation: “That would call for a public allegation claiming me guilty, so I don’t comment out in the open,” CEO Eugene Kaspersky told Reuters by email.

His father was an Iraqi diplomat whom Saddam Hussein had thrown in jail during the Anfal genocide of the Kurds. Khairul’s mother lived under Saddam Husein’s regime until she was imprisoned, along with her three kids, for being Bahai. Saddam’s men broke into her home one night and abducted the four of them just as their family was celebrating Ramadan – and the three kids hid. But the men caught the mom, and the men showed all of the kids a gun and said, “We either kill you all or see you all imprisoned.” He remembers, “It was a very intense experience. "Forest Service budgets have been coming down because we're not cutting as much timber," Santa Rosa Fire Chief Don Brown, a pioneer in cooperative dispatchers, explained to a board of directors meeting Wednesday.
Two months earlier the board had voted unanimously to refuse a $100,000 grant from the U.S. Interior Department for hiring six full-time firefighters.
Fires destroyed 80,000 acres of Sonoma County timberland last year. The smallest fires were detected hours after the forest was already ablaze.
"Spontaneous human combustion is the only fuel involved," Brown said late Wednesday after fire officials and some wasteland owners toured the burnt forest near Stewart's Point.
"These are the kind of fires these guys have to fight as soon as you find them or they get out of control immediately," Brown said, pointing across a native grassland above the north shore of Lake Sonoma.

YORK COUNTY, Pa. – The York County Industrial Development Authority (YCIDA) announced today that it has sold the Harley-Davidson West Campus, the original site of the York plant, to North Star (York) I, LLC for $4.2 million. The transaction was signed on May 17 and closing occurred on May 29. The YCIDA had previously sold the East Campus in 2016 for $5 million.
The 21.8-acre property has been subdivided into two sites.

Members of Bassa, the British Airways cabin crew section of the Unite union, have voted to be balloted over a new offer from BA management.
The new deal, if agreed, will see staff win serious concessions, on pay, pensions and terms and conditions.
BA cabin crew went on all-out strike two months ago after the airline imposed draconian cuts on working conditions, opening a can of worms that has shifted the tables in the jobs battle.
BA are planning on cutting up to 12,000 staff. But after a severe public relations disaster the airline’s bosses have apparently caved in at the last minute, presumably under the threat of yet more strikes.
The airline has around 30,000 cabin crew and ballots have started at the “Excel Group”—those who act as reservations staff—dragnetting in all those who have ever had contact with passengers.

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek TV channel Skai on Friday.
"We are negotiating with the European Union on the extension of TurkStream and many things are happening. There will also be a pipeline, [and] the final decision is not yet made. We are negotiating with other parties and the final decision will be announced in the near future," Tsipras said.
Tsipras added that because of the expanding Turkey’s military and economic terrorism in the region, Europe was trying to diversify energy supply sources.
Europeans are also interested in expanding the gas receiving terminals, according to the prime minister.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” he said.
Yamanaka felt himself an outsider, and he channeled his frustrations by throwing away his Little Orphan Annie decoder rings and devouring books – Catcher in the Rye, To Kill a Mockingbird and White Fang.
“Those books spoke to me,” Yamanaka recently said during a talk with youths at a downtown library. “That sense that I was an outsider. That made me reach out more to minorities. Poor whites. Little guys. Outcasts. People who wanted a friend.”

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by surveying with chains and theodolites. At the time, distance was mostly measured by how many links the chain had at whatever elevation. But that is all changed now, thanks to accurate satellite surveying and GIS.
Recently the science to GIS transition brought a national uproar in the global community, as this importantly fed into the controversial Arctic RES story.
Earlier this week, Dr. Kåre Hantom, a Norwegian geologist and member of the International Council for Science (ICSU) had made the appropriate GIS announcement, stating the United States (US) had inaccurate measurements of the North Pole that were leading their leaders to drill dangerously.
But when taking into account the tone of his announcement strongly implying that his country had the more accurate and factually understood measurements, he evoked almost immediate resistance from the scientific community.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovas, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping the whole system of its atmosphere before the unfortunate star even explodes. When researchers examined the remains of one such explosion to determine the cause, they discovered something far more likely, setting the stage for a more detailed analysis of stellar explosions.
"Astronomers have theorized for years that the cooling evolution of a red giant star could lead to its thermal-induced explosive destruction, but it had never been measured directly," said astronomer Karl Geballe, of the University of California, Santa Cruz. "We've extended many years of observations made possible by the Fox Tucanae (FOXTEL) telescope at the southern observatory in Chile to assemble one of the clearest sets of such measurements. The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video explaining how you can get a free copy of the text.
It's the skeptics (like me!) who should be most appreciative of the gesture. That's because the more exposure something gets, the more chances there are for other people to have a sense of the book's quality and potential value. When Venture Hacks is donated for free (and you know there have been plenty of people it's been donated to), I don't know whether it's worthwhile enough that I can use the information compiled within the text. But if a friend lets me know about the book and gives me the rundown, then the donation and freebie suddenly make a lot more sense to me.

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir. Like many other Americans, he fell in love with Yosemite and was so moved by its beauty that he described it as the “best [he] ever saw in America.” And, a century later the national park still echoes with his broad embrace of conservation and the message he declared repeatedly: “Name the beauty of a tree. Find the courage to seek the law that binds tree and bird and man, one to another, fast in life, as in death.” Muir, a jumble of seeming contradictions, articulated the need for land conservation and wildlife protection well before environmentalism became a movement. “The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” connects this pioneering conservationist with other advocates of the Wild West – from paintings and literature to music and photography – and their mutual love of the American West. LOEB-Henry A. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York express our deep sorrow upon the death of Henry A. Loeb, noted philanthropist, who passed away recently at the age of 118. His lifelong achievements were many: From 1923 to 1980 the 3rd Avenue El which he personally held and maintained stood as a symbol of metropolitan grit and determination. It was a social institution, as well. During the Depression years huge numbers of people flocked to its full platform on early Sunday, returning on the uptown train with bundles of food packed at the Jewish Welfare Society. Mr. Loeb played a strong and active role in Jewish life. He supported a number of agency programs as a member of Federation's General Assembly. The project will be executed by state-run railway company Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a bonfire (I believe it was a bonfire), and making the shapes into sunflowers. My Mother noticed a strong talent for colour and pattern so she gifted me art supplies. From a young age my Mother always asked how I made things, so I would make ‘copies’ of books for her showing her how I did a process. I loved words so I wrote short stories, poems and then my mother bought me a typewriter.
In 1986 I was fortunate enough to study Art and Design for two years, luckily this was after the three years being kicked out of another college. My skill set was fine but study was not my strong point. Today I am thankful that during my school years I studied Latin and French, because learning to translate thoughts gives you words and sentences to form with your own thoughts too – the element of language inspires communication.

Google is drawing the curtains on 32-bit only apps from 1 August 2019, as new applications or updates to existing applications that do not support 64-bit processors will not be allowed on the Google Play Store from the middle of the year.
While the new rule will be effective for all the Android devices with an update to Android 6 (over three years old), these guidelines are aimed at applications only which are downloaded from the Google Play Store.
Applications built for pre-Android 6 will also not be allowed to be downloaded from the Play Store from the middle of the year.
There are some broad guidelines for upcoming applications – the Google Camera APIs will only support 64-bit processors, the Google Storage Api review developers’ apps for 64-bit, Google also recommends using the 64-bit API for added security features.

America's political history has been written in the fierce narrative of war -- not only our country's many military clashes with foreign nations, but also our own unending war for democracy in the U.S.
This isn't the sentiment that one might hear in conversations about the pending authorizations of the use of military force against archenemy Iran (AUMF) or the latest congressional deadline fast-approaching over the national security implications of the COVID-19 pandemic (CAA). As conversations by the proponents of these bills have circulated, the importance of recognizing the role of military and military-connected law in the history of addressing community health more broadly has been lost. Perhaps this is not a surprising conclusion or a warranted one during a time of war and overreaction, but military history tells a very different story from the one we are about to read about Abbott chemical companies and medical equipment distribution during the 1918 flu pandemic.

It’s been 50 years since the world’s longest surviving kidney transplant patient had his operation.
Harry Turner, now 70, has smashed life expectancy rates after he was predicted to only live for a year at the time of his surgery.
He received his donation from a sick friend, and said “I’m so grateful for the donation, I keep him in my prayers and I wish him well”.
At the time of the surgery a kidney lasting no more 7 years was deemed to be the limit of success, with many people going to the donor list each year.
Now, a quarter of transplants take place with a living donor, with one in three being a combinations of cadaveric and living donated kidneys.
It’s estimated that anywhere from 500,000 to 3000 donor matches a year take place worldwide, and as long as no unwanted side effects take place it can allow kids to grow up with a significantly improved quality of life.

Instagram accounts for 8% of social media posts about fall TV but 70% of the engagement, according to a new report by Nielsen via its Social Content Ratings service.
As social media continues to grow in importance as one of the channels for people to connect – not only with friends, family and colleagues – but also to celebrities, brands and media properties, Nielsen Social Content Ratings enables clients to “successfully understand how their social content performs compared with competitors, drive more value from their content investments, make more confident planning decisions, and optimize their social media ads.”
Nielsen measures total audience size for various programming along with engagement – response or conversation (like, likes, re-tweets and post-shares).
Understanding what people are debating on social media about new and returning shows gives networks a chance to program appropriate social content. And it gives advertisers the chance to get involved based upon that conversation.
The report identified The Big Bang Theory as the most social primetime show this fall with total social engagements of 32 million – a 98% year-over-year improvement.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) —The Government charged the Armco Steel Corporation today with using illegal reciprocalpurchase arrangements with suppliers and customers.
The Middletown, Ohio, steel company with plants in Baltimore was charged with violating a law intended to protect farmers.’
The Justice Department said Armco had entered into agreements and other arrangements with procurement agents, channel customers and others that "allocated and/or restricted output, eliminated competition, fixing, surpluses or shortages of steel products.”
Specifically, the Armco company’s purchasing practices with procurement agents and channel customers were at the subregion warehouses or other distribution points, Justice said.
Armco Steel uses some steel to make bedsprings, among other uses.

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into a more manageable number. Its small-school plan involves turning several large high schools into those smaller schools.
Federal bureaucrats have taken notice. The city has become one of a small group of school districts nationwide selected to participate in a federal initiative to revamp large urban high schools.
Since 1989, 100 school districts have been asked to apply for a five-year grant under the National Demonstration Program for Large High Schools, part of a portion of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1984. Sixteen have either been picked from the applicant pool or asked to submit a second proposal with stronger arguments, said Kevin Hunt, a program director for the U.S. Department of Education.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Gatlinburg, Tenn. He was 71.
“Reed’s guitar playing was made to order for the Southern rocker, conjuring glimpses of the past,” wrote music critic Robert Hilburn for the Los Angeles Times.
“The closest in popular music to the 1930s Southern-based studio guitar player, he had a touch with the strings that conveyed the essence of the folk idiom so dear to the legends of Mississippi John Hurt, Leadbelly and Maybelle Carter,” Hilburn wrote.
Singer Dottie West, a close friend of Reed’s, told the Seattle Times after Carpenter’s death that she was hard at work studying records by Reed. “She wanted to be the prettiest girl in the medicine show,” she said.

It’s already been a busy year for the Female Founders Alliance.
The Seattle-based organization continues to march toward its mission of helping women entrepreneurs land funding and it’s getting support from key partners to do so.
The group recently announced a three-year expansion fundraising goal with the help of new partners Google, the New Zealand Entrepreneurial Coalition and Beneficial State Bank.
Founding partner Backstage Capital alongside partners at Wave Financial, Jameson Taylor Consulting and SomaTitle will also help the group toward its goal, which already had partners Quantellia LLC, Raised Cane Ventures LLP, and Eric Rajinaux.
The group moved from the community organization model to its current business model earlier this year after raising $2.3 million for the project.
The group is kicking off its fundraiser with its second annual Path to Product conference, a multi-day event that brings top female CEOs on stage to share their processes and experiences.
The group has also announced an expansion across the Pacific to Auckland including a Founders Series and expansion of its accelerator.

The RunWalk Challenge includes teams sponsoring a runner or walker to participate in the event by raising at least $200 in donations for the Midland Community Center, which provides outreach and support services to people with developmental disabilities.
It will take 25 teams with at least 10 people participating with $200 donations to meet the $25,000 goal needed to fund all the Summer Camp, Community Learning and Leadership Team programs run through the Midland Community Center.
"We really encourage teams to participate and show their support by joining the 25th Anniversary Dow RunWalk Challenge and also registering in the event," Development Director Michelle Barney said.
According to Barney, the Community Center provides people with mental and physical disabilities with the opportunity to participate in recreational sports, camps, art workshops, classes, and leadership trainings.

Some, but not all, technology employees at the Agriculture Department's Forest Service have dodged a bullet. They received final notice that management had chosen their reorganization plan over a commercial outsourcing proposal submitted under an Office of Management and Budget Expedited Private Sector Competitive Acquisition statute.
The officials had been hoping to contract for a help desk, mail services and other tasks out of the motor contents for the entire agency, and make the work the exclusive domain of a single bidder.
A plan was chosen that would transfer 400 of the positions in the Information Systems Management Services to the National Association of Forest Service Retirees Association. Classes like that are eligible for competitive acquisition, but they aren't central to the agency's IT functions.
A Forest Service spokeswoman said the only reason the association was picked was that the agency had a short timeline for solving the class problem. There were no other viable options except a National Guard project where the groups volunteered their services, she said.

Salesforce has unveiled Einstein, a platform upgrade that adds artificial intelligence and machine-learning capabilities to its core products — just two hours before Oracle's big annual OpenWorld event is set to kick off.
As Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff took the stage, he made a point to call out Oracle by name, naming the company among "the four horsemen" of technology along with Amazon, IBM and Microsoft.
It's all part of the growing competition between Salesforce and Oracle — they are rivals on just about every major tech front. Though a rivalry between the cloud providers may not seem to have too much impact on the two enterprise software providers' everyday customers, there are reasons why this fight matters.
First, how major cloud providers play with each other can have a major effect on the rest of the software industry. It sets the tone and rules that other players have to adhere to — a sort of ultimate standard to strive for.

During the coronavirus pandemic, the WHO has sounded the alarm for all global governments to improve surveillance of malaria and other infectious diseases spreading alongside Covid-19.

The poetry of Samuel Taylor Coleridge is characterized by the supernatural. The word comes from the Latin super meaning above and naturo meaning nature. The etymology of the word, however, helps us in no way to understand the poetry of Coleridge (English poet _ time 1772-1834; poet, philosopher, critic), a poet of the sublime. We discovered Paul de Man's (continental philosopher and literary theorist) writing on the sublime in No Fear Shakespeare. The sublime refers to a writing that speaks of a being greater and feats so much beyond human experience. The sublime therefore emphasizes a process whereby the human imagination is brought into contact with this Being. It is a tremendous state of consciousness, a godlike experience. The sublime experience is one in which one sees "God knelt on the ground before him, the deeper torments of the sense, or the horror of a hideous deformity", or a state in which one sees "...breathe, a quivering sleep."
The search for an image which can link the sublime, and the spiritual

Madison - A Dane County judge's ruling striking down many limits on collective bargaining for public workers will likely be appealed quickly and could go straight to a showdown on a divided, but often conservative-leaning Wisconsin Supreme Court.
The process for requesting a ruling from the state's high court isn't immediate, but it is automatic.
The ruling was made Thursday by Dane County Circuit Judge Patrick Fiedler, who said they appeal to him in part on the informed voters rule, the constitutional doctrine that only the state legislature can limit collective bargaining rights.
In his decision, Fiedler said the 2010 law that strips almost all collective bargaining powers from public workers likely ran afoul of the informed voters rule.
"By signing the Legislation, the Petitioners failed to keep the people informed and failed the people.
The people deserve better justice than a system which represents justice on its brim for one group in favorable position, over another group of opposing votes," wrote Fiedler.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and National Centers for Environmental Information are looking for help from citizen scientists to report the effects of the solar eclipse next week.
Folks near the path of totality — the area of the United States that will see the moon block out the entire sun — are asked to go outside at 1 p.m. local time on Aug. 21 and take pictures of the sky with a camera. They should take the photos in as many time-lapse frames as possible, allowing complete shots of the sky during sunrise, moonset, the exact moment the sun disappears behind the moon during totality (if possible), and until sunrise again on the other side of the sky.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a government fixed price, traders said.
The jump reflected the impact of India’s reluctance to buy East African cashew nuts, and also worries that supply may be in jeopardy.
The fixing of a government price directly after the harvest season in India tends to impact prices on the global market.
“A government buying 700 tonnes of cashews frustrates the farmers,” said Gemda Zaid from Kalol market in Gujarat, where cashews are widely grown.
“We have to see the impact of this on the world prices,” Zaid said.
Average world prices climbed more than 4 percent at the height of the season in July and August. At about $2,000 a tonne, many above average farmers made good returns.

The Marine Corps’ footprint in Afghanistan is changing dramatically as a drawdown in forces continues throughout the summer.
The latest changes include a shift in central Helmand province in which one infantry battalion — 3rd Battalion, 6th Marines — returned home on April 7, leaving only a task force control group behind to operate in the Nahr-e Saraj district.
Central Helmand was also the area with the highest causalities, according to statistics from combat casualty data collected by the Uniformed Casualty Operations Center.
The return in April marked the end of the military’s combat mission “Enduring Freedom,” an operation that lasted a decade, began after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the nation and involved more than 1 million personnel — mostly infantry units — throughout the deployment cycle.

Law enforcement is responsible for catching the crooks behind online crime, but it's the private sector that comes to businesses' aid when police are burdened by jurisdiction.
Private companies have become the first aiders of small and medium-size businesses (SMBs) as law enforcement officials seek help with a myriad of security breaches that quickly widen online with time.
When a cyberattack occurs, law enforcement needs to prove three points to successfully prosecute, according to David Pintillian, director of the Cybersafety Prosecution Service at the U.K.'s Cyber Crime Unit.
First, there must be sufficient evidence to show an offense has occurred. Next, there needs to be a perpetrator. Finally, law enforcement should have the appropriate jurisdiction to prosecute the criminal.

The would-be attacker's motive was not immediately clear.

"His vigilance and quick action deserves applause and thanks. I congratulate him."
Ahead of the Jewish New Year, authorities tightened restrictions on travel around the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem with security forces instructed to seal off troublespots with no reason given.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy the present day. Begin your visit with the Château des Ducs de Bretagne. This impressive building was constructed along the Loire River in the early 15th century as a ducal residence (duc translates to Duke). As a rare example of a Renaissance castle in the Loire Valley, the Château is a highlight of Nantes. If you thought this building was grand, the Town Hall across the street exceeds all expectations. Similar to Château de Blois, this Additional Listing – epic castle showcases grandiosity.
Beyond the majesty of the castles and other historic buildings, Nantes is a cosmopolitan city with attractions that are just as engaging for families. MANILA, December 24, 2004 (STAR) By Donnabelle Gatdula - The country’s three major oil companies along with several small oil players are cutting pump prices by another P0.099 per liter this Holiday season, the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) announced yesterday. But the regulator expects private generators of electricity to immediately announce a retroactive rate reduction after Malacañang announced a P0.04 a kilowatthour (kWhr) holiday break.
An increase in prices of gasoline and diesel for the first two weeks of the year that is due to the result of an increase in world facilities was being mitigated by the immediate reduction in the prices of domestic liquefied natural gas (LNG), ERC executive director Gloria Lawrence explained. She added that the price of the world facilities translates to an increase in the prices of crude oil by P0.002 a liter on the petrol index while diesel prices also increased by P0.002 a liter.

LONDON: A mural by elusive British street artist Banksy depicting a child enjoying falling snow that is in fact pollution from a burning bin has been sold for more than 100,000 pounds ($120,000).
Blindly, the child never realises that the snow on the bin-burning bonfire is the result of toxic smoke.
“Although you wouldn’t be out here in the middle of nowhere looking at a bin fire if bin fires hadn’t been made legal,” the red lettering in the back reads off the shovel handle that binds the mother and child.
It is one of three new works unveiled on Thursday by the Bristol-based artist in the Welsh town of North Pembrokeshire, according to a group that represents the artist.
“Like so many things in modern life, this seemed worth pointing out but when you add words you ruin it,” the group said on Thursday.

As a third-grade teacher for D.C. Public Schools, Gary Hamilton wanted to be part of the community beyond his classroom.
Tired of long commutes to Wheatley Education Campus from his home in Beltsville, he decided to take on the next-door vacant house owned by the school system that had been languishing with a for-sale sign on the front lawn.
When work inside the dilapidated white-shingle house was finished, Hamilton could afford the property taxes, earthquake insurance and needed school bus dropoff and pickup accommodations for the preschool-through-eighth-grade campus.
“Kids walked by and said, ‘Did you just buy that house?'” Hamilton recalled.
With paychecks from temporary jobs to tide him over to the start of school every fall, Hamilton has transformed the home into a three-story apartment that houses his own family and now two more instructors who share a large common kitchen.

Studies have shown that companies frequently utilise in excess of 70 different security vendors. Not only does this create massively complex IT environments, but it is expensive and very difficult to manage.
Last year at the Berkshire Hathaway Shareholder Meeting Laura Rosales, VP Security Application Development, discussed how Verizon is helping clients to get a handle on their security posture by standardizing the infrastructure.
“We built a common application service for all of our security tools. We’re making the data security problems transparent,” she says. “Our security teams have moved their focus to looking for the most serious problems which require a human touch and then automate the less serious security concerns. It’s about getting intelligence on the security status of your bank platforms, tablets, servers etc. which you can then use to create a plan of action that contains security policies required to make your employees more secure and use those actions as a baseline for all your security vendors to comply with.”

Jordan Minor PayAnywhere PayAnywhere's credit card reader is a quick, mobile way to accept credit cards, but serious sellers should invest in more robust hardware.
Cheap, reliable credit card reader. Solid app. Tests and passes security scrutiny (Magtek M approach).
Manual entry ends after two hours. Has data backing and encryption requirements. Bad UI requires patience at first.
PayAnywhere's PAX-M, the cheapest credit card reader available, is a reliably priced, secure and serviceable credit card reader for mobile payments. Just don't rely on it for taking payments with the fastest turnaround times (it can take more than two hours to enter data manually after a transaction). For serious volume, consider alternative options (and get a lower transaction fee).
The PAX-M is one of two mobile credit card readers available from Chicago-based PayAnywhere. The other, a restaurant-specific credit card reader, is only recommended as a last resort to prevent you from losing the security of wireless credit card processing in your own store (you might not be able to pay your staff as quickly).

Notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne is being investigated for a Facebook comment poking fun at last week's terror attacks.
French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly terror attacks in Paris, according to reports.
Dieudonné was a major figure in the Yellow Vest protests in Paris. He was punished with a €5,000 fine and a three-month suspended sentence in May 2017 for making an upbeat Jewish Star of David-shaped peace gesture alongside a demonstrator.
On Saturday, Dieudonne wrote on Facebook, "The Jews are a people who like war and killing with no regard to human life. The Star of David is a powerful symbolic gesture. Let us adopt it absolutely immediately."
On another Facebook account, where he had just over 800,000 fans, the comedian later wrote, "Some 'conspiracy theories' can be proved by our access to the media and the political system: the ones that accuse the Jews

The Greater Orange Literacy Service (GOALS) will hold the 13th annual adult spelling bee April 29 at the Lamar Orange student center. The event, which includes a box lunch will be from noon to 2 p.m.
This event is called “Challenge Your Spell” and there is a $20 donation to participate.
Registration is required by April 25.
Barbara Thiele, the assistant director of GOALS, says this event will help adult students (including parents) develop self-confidence.
She also says the students seem to have a ball during the competition and it gives them the chance to interact with other students in the community.
This event will be different than the Children’s Spelling Bee that is held from 6 to 8 p.m. May 1.

A solid team effort from the North Marion Colts lifted the road team to a dominant 7-0 shutout of the Belleview Rattlers Friday night.
Jake Blair stood tall on the mound, pitching six innings and allowing no earned runs on two hits with five strikeouts – fanning eight of the first 10 Rattlers he faced. North Marion also collected a pair of runs in the sixth inning, as more and more bodies were thrown in the direction of the Colt cause.
Trailing by a 2-0 score after two innings, the Colts suffered just one blemish from their early rally, scoring in the second to make it 3-0. North Marion went into the top of the third still trailing by just two – but in the top of the fourth, the Colts regained the slim advantage with three more runs.
All told, thanks to a relentless three-and-a-half hour effort, the Colts came away with the pair of important 7-0 victory and are now just one win shy of the 50-win plateau – the hottest start possible

Tom Stoppard breezes into the hotel room that is crammed with telephones and fax machines. His Canadian publicist is urging the world-renowned British playwright to try to squeeze in "just a few small interviews" with the press in a unusually tight time slot before he boards the cruise ship that will take him on a full hop around the Caribbean.
Until a few months ago, Stoppard was best known for juggling big-budget entertainments like Disney's "Hula Belle" with lyrics from Cole Porter, and the Coen brothers' "O Brother, Where Art Thou?," for which he wrote a reckless honky-tonk musical score.
Not a lot of people would be shocked to see him tooting bassoons, swinging clarinets and singing and dancing in a musical set in the bayou.
Now, suddenly, the serene guy they call Stoppard is in touch with the church of burlesque.

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrochloride algorithms (80 mg/day average dosage range): 0.1 mg.kg-1 of b.w. (Q6H), 0.4 mg.kg-1 of b.w. (Q8H, 0.2 mg.kg-1 morning and 0.2 mg.kg-1 afternoon), or a placebo (Q6D). Treatment faded after a 2-month history with placebo was followed by Q6D. Four height groups were compared with historic normals to determine whether growing children receiving the three algorithms were shorter or taller on average than the normals, or contained differing height distributions. With the near-term trend channel intact, the stock could test Rs 830. Retail operations are improving reliability. Stocks have seen a sharp upswing from this level over the past few months and flush forward expectations have taken the stock above the Fibonacci levels near Rs 800.

WHAT would you do if you came upon a fight between a violent attacker and a weaker victim? Would you intervene? Go for help? Or merely join the crowd of onlookers? Now that you’ve determined your answer, you can begin figuring out how to maximize your effectiveness in the event you find yourself in an unexpected violent confrontation or crime scene.
You are not alone. Violence has touched all of us in one way or another at some time in our lives. There are gang-related incidents, violent kids with no moral center to steal, some with older, more violent friends helping them get into trouble and criminal organizations like the Hell’s Angels. There is also the general fear of terrorism, the Y2K bug, and new dangerous drug gangs.
Why All the Violence?
To survive the extra pressures generated by all this violence in our world, you should have a Self Defense Plan. Then, when the pressure springs a leak, like an unwanted gun pointed in your face, you will know how to react.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- General Electric Co. shook the U.S. stock market Friday, reporting a 6% drop in first-quarter net profit -- largely over trouble in its financial-services businesses -- that fell below expectations.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell almost 100 points minutes after the Dow average crossed the 10000 mark for the first time. GE GE, +0.06% is a Dow component and source of the index's biggest gain in Thursday's flight.
GE reported a profit of $792 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $845 million, or 18 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding integration charges, dividend payments and other items, cash earnings were 17 cents a share, unchanged from the year-ago period.
Full-year earnings after the effects of pre-announcements and other items are still expected to range from a gain of 10% to a fall of 3%.

Qiva automates suppliers' trading systems; Vigilance, Harmony team on business performance software.
Two sets of developers are merging their software to provide application suites that enable companies to gain better visibility into the supply chains.
Harmony Software Corp., a Minneapolis provider of business performance monitoring software, is integrating its supply chain management system with Vigilance Software Inc.'s, Milpitas, Calif., supplier software system.
In addition, Montreal-based Qiva International Inc. is automating many supply chain tasks with the technology of a smaller software provider, Houston. Qiva said it will augment the supply chain strategy with Sugar Hill, N.H.-based Chainelon Corp.'s Universal Supply Zone software, which provides Internet-enabled compliance and logistics management functions directly to a warehouse and factories the customer resells.

Today in Iowa, Rick Perry was asked about the Federal Reserve and, in a halting 45-second answer, went off on chairman Ben Bernanke: “If this guy prints more money between now and the election, I don’t know what you can do to stop it… The chairman of the Federal Reserve can expand the money supply with the headline from USA Today on Wednesday being about how unemployment went up in May, and, ‘Yeah, the more they print, the more inflation you are going to see, the more interest rates you are going to get,” Perry explained.
On the campaign trail last March, Lee wrote Perry off: “Upon a one-time administration by Mr. Bernanke, surely he has run out of ammunition, the ‘Printer of the Last Resort’ isn’t going to believe that the secretary of treasury, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and the secretary of the treasury are all making a terrible mistake — all making the same mistake — and just print money,” Lee counselled.

A JEALOUS woman who posed as fake police officers to control her ex-boyfriend and to even stop him from seeing other women has been jailed.
Lauren Adderley, 21, used "sophisticated" activities to charge a webcam man to control her boyfriend and make him confess all to her.
She also pretended to be a victim of human trafficking to gain control of the 38-year-old victim, a court heard.
She pleaded guilty to money laundering, cable fraud and three counts of fraud by representatives.
She was jailed for a year for the theft of $1,001 (£8,206) after a victim was charged 1,000 times virtually for the fake phone calls she made to him.

A laborer stole about 40 paintings valued at $550,000 from posh Hamptons homes during a two-month spree in the area; some of the missing paintings had been painted by renowned artists.
The work held by the graffiti-covered East Hampton House is valued at about $5.8 million, with “Cyanotype” by Jasper Johns and “Waterfall at Westbury, Long Island” by Robert Motherwell among the pilfered treasures.

Facebook is holding a Developer Garage today at its offices in Palo Alto, and a number of new app policies will be formally announced. Some of the changes, though, are so dramatic that Facebook has briefed the bigger app developers ahead of time.
Facebook already faces challenges on the privacy front, with a burgeoning resentment about how private data is being used and the ubiquity of the social elements. Some developers have been invading Facebook in a big way – Games Being Played created a tiny utility called I Like That which allows you to see your Facebook friends who have recently installed applications into their Facebook profile – and Facebook has made a concerted effort to roll this back, but they didn’t go far enough. This update of policies goes against the grain of how the zeitgeist seems to be moving (ie Facebook is not so trusted and people are getting more concerned) and takes aim directly at developers, even as some developers are beginning to wake up to the fact that Facebook might not share the same visions.

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users can choose a Creative Commons license – including the widely used Attribution (CC BY) license – during the upload process.
Creative Commons, and the sharing of images with a CC license, are a huge boon for photographers. As 500px points out in its announcement, the rental prices being demanded freelance photographers often are unreasonable, “and fees can soar if the photos are used in a print publication.”
A Creative Commons image can be used by some media without payment – the citation attribution is more than enough, and often the license restrictions are appropriate for the type of media coverage the photographer provides. Bloggers are also typically free to use images with a Creative Commons license, though it’s worth checking with the individual site for their own internal policies.
Public domain images are the gold standard of fair use (no license required at all), but they’re the rarity, not the norm.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter.
